item.title: India plans to build satellite tracking station in Vietnam that can monitor China
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twIndian officials say their country plans to build a satellite tracking and imaging center in southern Vietnam, which would give Hanoi access to images of the region from Indian earth observation satellites, including China and the South China Sea, Reuters reported.The satellite tracking and data reception center will be established in Ho Chi Minh City to monitor Indian satellite launches. Indian media say it will cost about $23 million. The facility, however, will also be equipped to receive images from the 11 earth observation satellites India has in orbit. The Vietnamese will be able to directly access images from Indian satellites that cover the region. These will include images of China and the South China Sea, as well as images of Chinese naval bases, its coastguard and navy, and its new man-made islands in the disputed Spratly archipelago.The earth observation satellites images have civilian agricultural, scientific and environmental applications, but can also be used for military purposes.Collin Koh, a marine security expert at Singapore's S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies, told Reuters: “In military terms, this move could be quite significant. It looks like a win-win for both sides, filling significant holes for the Vietnamese and expanding the range for the Indians."India also has satellite-tracking stations in the Andaman and Nicobar islands, Brunei, Biak in eastern Indonesia and Mauritius.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. A satellite tracking and data reception center in Ho Chi Minh City monitoring Indian satellite launches2. The facility receiving images from India's 11 earth observation satellites3. Vietnamese will have access to images of China and the South China Sea, Chinese coastal naval bases, the Chinese coastguard and navy, and China’s new man-made islands4. Indian satellites images having agricultural, scientific, and environmental as well as military applications5. Indian satellite-tracking stations in the Andaman and Nicobar islands, Brunei, Biak in Indonesia and MauritiusVOICEOVER (in English): “The satellite tracking and data reception center will be built in Ho Chi Minh City to monitor Indian satellite launches.”“The facility will also be able to receive images from the 11 earth observation satellites India has in orbit.”“The Vietnamese will be able to directly access images from Indian satellites that cover the region. These will include images of China and the South China Sea, as well as images of Chinese naval bases, its coastguard and navy, and its new man-made islands in the disputed Spratly archipelago.”“The earth observation satellites have civilian agricultural, scientific and environmental applications, but can also be used for military purposes.”“India also has ground stations in the Andaman and Nicobar islands, Brunei, Biak in eastern Indonesia and Mauritius.” SOURCES: Reutershttp://in.reuters.com/article/india-vietnam-satellite-china-idINKCN0V309W***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Birth defect that causes intestines to protrude from a baby’s abdomen on the rise in the U.S.
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twIncidents of a birth defect that causes a newborn’s intestines to protrude from the abdomen are on the rise in the United States, especially among African Americans, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.The condition, called gastroschisis, is a defect in the abdominal wall. When a baby is affected by gastroschisis, the intestines, and sometimes also organs such as the liver and stomach, stick out from the abdomen through a hole next to the belly button. The Los Angeles Times reports that from 1994 to 2012, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have documented a 263 percent increase in gastroschisis among babies born to black mothers under the age of 20. About 2,000 babies are born with the birth defect every year. Health officials struggling to understand the cause. "This isn't new. I saw cases when I was a brand new trainee long ago,” James Greenberg, co-director of the Perinatal Institute and director of Neonatology at Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, told CBS News, “but they were really unusual then."Although the condition can be life-threatening, it can often be remedied by surgery in the weeks after the baby is born.Even after surgery, however, some infants can have problems eating and digesting food, because the organs have been irritated by exposure to amniotic fluid in the uterus, increasing the risk of problems such as stunted growth or malnutrition.Although researchers do not know what causes gastroschisis, they suspect that a mother’s diet, consumption of tobacco, alcohol and medicines, exposure to toxins and sexually transmitted diseases during pregnancy are all factors that could have an effect on the development of an abdominal wall defect, the Los Angeles Times reported. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Gastroschisis cases on the rise in the U.S. from 1994 to 20122. The intestines, and sometimes the stomach and liver, sticking out of the baby’s belly; number of cases in the U.S. each year3. Gastroschisis surgery, possible problems and risks after surgeryVOICEOVER (in English): “From 1994 to 2012, the CDC has documented a 263 percent increase in gastroschisis among babies born to black mothers under the age of 20.” “When a baby is affected by gastroschisis, the intestines, and sometimes also organs such as the liver and stomach, protrude from the abdomen through a hole next to the bellybutton.” “In the U.S. about 2,000 babies are born with the birth defect every year.” “Although the condition can be life-threatening, it can often be remedied by surgery in the weeks after the baby is born.”“Even after surgery, however, some infants can have problems eating and digesting food, increasing the risk of problems such as stunted growth and malnutrition. This is because the organs have been irritated by exposure to amniotic fluid in the uterus.” SOURCES: Los Angeles Times, CBS Newshttp://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-bizarre-birth-defect-rise-cdc-20160121-story.htmlhttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/serious-birth-defect-is-on-the-rise-says-cdc/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Plastic in oceans will outweigh fish by 2050, Davos report says
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twBy 2050, plastic rubbish in the ocean will outweigh fish, according to a new report by the Ellen MacArthur Foundation released at the World Economic Forum in Davos this week.According to the report, the United States, Europe and Asia together account for 85 percent of plastics production, roughly split between the U.S. and Europe on one side and Asia on the other. The report found that 95 percent of plastic packaging is lost to the economy each year after a single use, at a cost of an estimated $80 billion to $120 billion.Only five percent of all plastic produced each year is recycled effectively, while around 40 percent is buried in landfills. About 32 percent roughly 8 million tonnes reaches the world’s oceans, the equivalent of dumping the contents of one garbage truck into the ocean each minute. As developing countries continue to grow and therefore consume more, the production of plastic, which currently stands at around 311 million tonnes a year, is expected to quadruple by 2050. This will bring the ratio of plastic to fish in the ocean, calculated according to weight, from 1:5 to more than 1:1. The report urges people to take action and to rethink the way we use and recycle plastic. It also suggests that manufactures help reduce plastic waste by producing not only plastic that is reusable but also compostable plastics, a new generation of plastics that are biodegradable through composting.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. U.S., Europe and Asia’s shares of of plastic production2. 95 percent of plastic packaging produced each year is lost after a single use3. Five percent of plastic is recycled, 40 percent buried in landfills, and 32 percent reaches the oceans4. Garbage truck dumping plastic in ocean5. Production of plastic quadrupling from 2014 to 20506. Ratio of plastic to fish in the ocean going from 1:5 in 2014 to more than 1:1 in 2050VOICEOVER (in English): “The United States, Europe and Asia together account for 85 percent of plastics production, roughly split between the U.S. and Europe on one side and Asia on the other.” “Some 95 percent of plastic packaging produced each year is lost to the economy after a single use.”“Out of all the plastic produced every year, only five percent is recycled effectively. Around 40 percent is buried in landfills, and about 32 percent reaches the oceans.”“This corresponds to dumping the contents of one garbage truck into the ocean every minute.”“The production of plastic, which now stands at around 311 million tonnes a year, is expected to quadruple by 2050.” “This will bring the ratio of plastic to fish in the ocean, calculated according to weight, from 1:5 to more than 1:1.” SOURCES: Ellen MacArthur Foundation, IFL Science http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_The_New_Plastics_Economy.pdfhttp://www.iflscience.com/environment/plastic-oceans-could-outweigh-fish-2050***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Head transplant successfully performed on monkey
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA monkey head transplant was successfully performed at a university in China, claims Italian neurosurgeon Sergio Canavero. The experiment was carried out at Harbin Medical University in China, reported the New Scientist. The researchers reportedly connected the blood supply between the head and the new body, but did not connect the spinal cord.“The monkey fully survived the procedure without any neurological injury of whatever kind,” New Scientist quoted Dr. Canavero as saying. The monkey was kept alive for only 20 hours following the procedure for ethical reasons.Other techniques to aid recovery could include spinal cord stimulation and the use of a negative pressure device to encourage the nerves to fuse, the New Scientist reported. According to the New Scientist, Dr. Canavero is seeking funds to perform a head transplant on 31-year-old Russian patient Valery Spriridonov, who suffers from a genetic muscle-wasting disease.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Two heads severed from two medical bodies2. Polyethylene glycol added to the wound3. Depiction of spinal cord stimulation4. Negative pressure device is applied5. Head is cooled to -15 °C6. The spinal cord and blood vessels are connectedVOICEOVER (in English): [CUT 1]Italian Doctor Sergio Canavero claims a human head transplant could be successful. First both patient and donors’ heads are severed. An adhesive known as polyethylene glycol would then be used to preserve nerve cell membranes.”[CUT 2]“Spinal cord stimulation could speed a potential patient’s recovery.”[CUT 3]“A negative pressure device would encourage nerves to connect.”[CUT 4] Canavero told New Scientist Chinese researchers who claim to have performed a head transplant on a monkey say the head was cooled to -15 °C without injury to the brain. The spinal cord was not connected and, for ethical reasons, the monkey was euthanized less than a day later.”SOURCES: New Scientist, Daily Mail, Discoveryhttps://www.newscientist.com/article/2073923-head-transplant-carried-out-on-monkey-claims-maverick-surgeon/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3408400/Surgeon-claims-carried-HEAD-transplant-live-monkey-Controversial-trial-lead-procedure-humans.htmlhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3227954/Human-head-transplant-edges-closer-reality-Chinese-surgeon-teams-Italian-doctor-perform-procedure-2017.htmlhttp://news.discovery.com/tech/biotechnology/head-transplant-performed-on-monkey-claims-surgeon-160119.htm***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: How the Mirai hydrogen fuel cell from Toyota works
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twAnimation: Next AnimationVideo: Theresa Chong, Next AnimationToyota showcased its hydrogen fuel cell vehicle for the mass market, called the Mirai, at the 2016 San Francisco Auto Show last November. “Once we extract hydrogen out of things, it’s a limitless source of fuel,” said Chris Petschler, product specialist at Toyota. “We don’t burn it, so it’s completely clean.” Petschler says Toyota sees this as the fuel of the future. “You fill the tanks with compressed hydrogen gas– pure hydrogen,” Petschler said. “Whenever you step on the accelerator, it feeds hydrogen into the fuel cell, which then mixes with oxygen, which we just get from the ambient air. We have two scoops on the front end of the car and a compressor that pushes oxygen in. The hydrogen and oxygen want to bind, but we force them through a micron thin layer of platinum. So, the electron can’t make that binding process, so it kind of goes around. We capture that as electricity, and then the hydrogen and the oxygen bind on the other side, which is H2O. All we’re left with is water vapor, that’s the byproduct. And, then the electricity of course runs the car.” Although driving a car that emits water vapor could be a bonus, Petschler said there are still a few hurdles ahead. “Getting the infrastructure into place, getting more pumps, that is our challenge,” Petschler said. According to the U.S. Department of Energy’s website, there are only 14 public hydrogen-fueling stations in the United States, and 11 of them are in California. Petschler says Toyota is working towards a solution. Petschler said Toyota is working towards a solution. “We’re releasing our patents on the car and fuel cell stations. So, we have a company called First Element that’s helping us in California, Air Liquide in France.” The Mirai accelerates from zero to 60 miles per hour in nine seconds, and it takes around five minutes to refuel.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Toyota Mirai Hydrogen Fuel Cell Vehicle2. Chris Petschler interview3. Toyota Mirai4. Animation explaining how the hydrogen fuel cell vehicle tech works. Voiceover by Chris Petschler.5. Toyota Mirai hurdles6. Chris Petschler interview7. U.S. Department of Energy stats8. Chris Petschler interview9. Toyota Mirai statsVOICEOVER (in English): “VO: Toyota showcased its hydrogen fuel cell vehicle, called the Mirai, at the 2016 San Francisco Auto Show last November. According to Toyota Product Specialist, Chris Petschler”“Petschler: Once we extract hydrogen out of things, it’s a limitless source of fuel. We don’t burn it, so it’s completely clean.”“VO: Petschler says Toyota sees this as the fuel of the future, but how does it actually work?“Petschler: You fill the tanks with compressed hydrogen gas– pure hydrogen. Whenever you step on the accelerator, it feeds hydrogen into the fuel cell, which then mixes with oxygen, which we just get from the ambient air. We have two scoops on the front end of the car and a compressor that pushes oxygen in. The hydrogen and oxygen want to bind, but we force them through a micron thin layer of platinum. So, the electron can’t make that binding process, so it kind of goes around. We capture that as electricity, and then the hydrogen and the oxygen bind on the other side, which is H2O. All we’re left with is water vapor, that’s the byproduct. And, then the electricity of course runs the car.“VO: Although driving a car that emits water vapor could be a bonus, there are still a few hurdles ahead.” “Petschler: Getting the infrastructure into place, getting more pumps, that is our challenge.”“VO: According to the U.S. Department of Energy’s website, there are only 14 public hydrogen-fueling stations in the United States, and 11 of them are in California. Petschler says Toyota is working towards a solution.”“Petschler: We’re releasing our patents on the car and fuel cell stations. So, we have a company called First Element that’s helping us in Califor

item.title: Researchers discover evidence of Neptune-sized ninth planet
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twResearchers at the California Institute of Technology (Caltech) have discovered evidence of a ninth planet beyond the orbit of Pluto.According to an article on Caltech’s website, Konstantin Batygin and Mike Brown, discovered the existence of the planet that’s been called “Planet Nine” through mathematical modeling and computer simulations. While evidence shows the strong possibility of the new planet, researchers are still looking to make a visual observation. The discovery and observation of dwarf planets and other small objects in the outer solar system have led researchers to believe that a larger hidden planet exists. The smaller bodies have orbits that appear to have been perturbed, or influenced by the gravity of a larger mass.The theory was originally set forth in a 2014 paper by Scott Sheppard of the Washington-based Carnegie Institution of Science and Chad Trujillo of the Gemini Observatory in Hawaii, which discussed the potential existence of a giant planet affecting the orbits of those dwarf worlds.Batygin and Brown set out to debunk the theory, but ended up only finding supporting facts.The planet is predicted to be 10 times the mass of Earth and to orbit about 20 times further from the sun than Neptune. It is estimated that it would take 10,000 to 20,000 years for Planet Nine to complete an orbit around the sun. Its size and gravitational dominance over smaller objects in its solar neighborhood, according to researchers, make it undoubtedly a planet, unlike Pluto which has been reclassified as a dwarf planet.The observations of Planet Nine is similar to that of the 19th century revelation of Neptune when researchers observed perturbations in Uranus’ orbit as a result of the larger neighboring planet. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Orbit of planets around system2. Orbit of planets and planet nine3. Uranus and Neptune4. Planets orbiting on one side of sun5. Telescope searching for planet nineVOICEOVER (in English): "While it takes Earth one year and Jupiter roughly 12 years to complete an orbit, it is estimated that Planet Nine takes 10,000 to 20,000 years to circle the sun.""The planet was discovered through observations of dwarf planets and small objects in the outer solar system.""In 1846, astronomers observed the orbit of Uranus and noticed discrepancies that suggested something was pulling on it. That force became realized as the planet Neptune.""Fast forward less than two centuries later, and researchers again noticed deviations in the orbit of objects and dwarf planets in the outer solar system. All of them seem to orbit on one side of the sun.""A worldwide search is now in place for a visual of Planet Nine. Once a visual is made, it will officially be welcomed to our solar system as a full-fledged planet"SOURCES: California Institute of Technologyhttp://www.caltech.edu/news/caltech-researchers-find-evidence-real-ninth-planet-49523***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Just 62 individuals have as much wealth as half of the world’s population: Oxfam
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twJust 62 people have as much wealth as half the planet’s population, according to an Oxfam report, released as politicians and business leaders gather at the World Economic Forum in Davos.And the wealth gap is getting bigger, Oxfam says. In 2009, the world’s richest one percent owned 44 percent of global wealth, and 2014 saw that figure rise to 48 percent. Oxfam has also calculated that as few as 62 individuals, 53 of them men, have the same wealth as 3.5 billion people, Reuters reported. The report comes as an urgent call to action, inviting governments to tackle this growing inequality. “It is time for the global leaders of modern capitalism, in addition to our politicians, to work to change the system to make it more inclusive, more equitable and more sustainable,” said Lady Lynn Forester de Rothschild, chief executive officer of E.L. Rothschild and chairman of the Coalition for Inclusive Capitalism, who was quoted by Oxfam.Among the measures to distribute global wealth more equally, Oxfam suggests clamping down on tax-dodging by corporations and rich individuals, investing in universal, free public services such as education and health care, and sharing the tax burden more fairly. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. The world’s richest one percent wealth increasing since 20092. The owners of the remaining global wealth 3. The wealth of 62 individuals being the same as 3.5 billion people4. In 2010, the wealth of 388 being the same as 3.5 billion peopleVOICEOVER (in English): [CUT 1]In 2009, the world’s richest owned 44 percent of global wealth. By 2014 that figure had jumped to 48 percent and it could hit 50 percent this year.[CUT 4] to editors: please show in the animation cut 4 then cut 2 and 3 - thanksOf the remaining global wealth, almost all is owned by the richest fifth of the world’s population. As little as 5.5 percent of what’s left is shared by the other 80 percent. [CUT 2 and 3]Oxfam also calculated that as few as 62 individuals now have equal wealth to 3.5 billion people, a number that decreased from 388 individuals in 2010. SOURCES: Oxfam, The Guardian, Bloomberg https://www.oxfam.org/en/pressroom/pressreleases/2015-01-19/richest-1-will-own-more-all-rest-2016http://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/jan/18/richest-62-billionaires-wealthy-half-world-population-combinedhttp://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-18/richest-1-now-wealthier-than-the-rest-of-the-world-oxfam-says***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,Global wealth,wealth inequality,Oxfam,report,richest people,world population,inequality,poverty,1 percent,nma,next media animation,Taiwanese animators

item.title: Chinese company unveils drone that can carry human passengers
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA Chinese company has revealed what it says is the world’s first autonomous aerial vehicle (AAV), or drone capable of carrying a passenger.Ehang unveiled the Ehang 184 supersized single seater quad copter this week at the Consumer Electronics Show CES in Las Vegas.The Ehang 184’s aluminum frame and composite body carry eight 142 horsepower motors to power its eight propellers, with two propellers on each of the drone’s four arms. It takes between two to fours hours to charge.According to the company, the user can simply get get in, power up the drone, select a destination and the drone will take care of everything else.It can fly a 264-pound (120-kg) passenger at an altitude of above 11,000 ft, travelling at speeds of up to 62 mph for up to 23 minutes with a range of around 10 miles.Navigation and collision avoidance is taken care of by the drone’s range of built-in sensors and computer systems. When not in use, the vehicle’s rotor arms can be folded up for convenient storage.The manufacturer says the drone will be commercially available later this year, with a price somewhere between $200,000 and $300,000. It is now working toward getting certification from the FAA.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Depiction of the Ehang 184, and charging time (2-4 hours)2. Depiction of user beginning flight3. Details of altitude, speed and range of Ehang 1844. Depiction of Ehang’s autonomous navigation technology5. Depiction of Ehang landing6. Folding away of Ehang’s four rotor armsVOICEOVER (in English): "The Ehang 184’s aluminum frame and composite body carry eight 142 horsepower motors to power its eight propellers, with two situated on each of the drone’s four arms. It takes between two to fours hours to charge.""According to the company, the user can simply get in, power up the drone, select a destination and the device will take care of everything else." "It can fly a 264-lb passenger up to an altitude of around 11,000 ft, travelling at speeds of up to 62 mph for up to 23 minutes with a maximum range of around 10 miles.""Navigation and collision avoidance is taken care of by the drone’s range of built-in sensors and computer systems.""Once passengers arrive at their destination, the dronés rotor arms can be folded up for convenient storage."SOURCES: GIZMAGhttp://www.gizmag.com/ehang-184-aav-passenger-drone/41213/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Zika virus case confirmed in Texas, woman infected during trip to El Salvador
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA woman who returned to the Houston area in Texas after a trip to El Salvador in November has a confirmed case of the Zika virus, Reuters reported, citing officials in Harris County. According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, there have been 22 cases of the disease among returning U.S. travelers since 2007. Zika is transmitted by the Aedes genus of mosquito, which can also carry the dengue and chikungunya viruses. Zika causes a mild disease with fever, rash and joint pain. It is rarely fatal and can be cured with bed rest and liquids.An epidemic of the Zika virus in Brazil, however, has prompted health officials to investigate thousand of cases of microcephaly in the country. Since microcephaly is usually a rare condition, health officials have suggested a link between the virus and the disease that causes an abnormally small head size and incomplete brain development.According to the Wall Street Journal, Brazilian authorities estimate that 500,000 to 1.5 million people have been infected by the Zika virus in the country. In December, Puerto Rico confirmed its first locally acquired case of Zika virus, suggesting that the virus might be circulating there. U.S. officials say they are preparing for a growing number of Zika cases in the spring and summer, when the weather creates ideal breeding conditions for the mosquitoes that carry the virus.Outbreaks of the virus have also occurred in the past in Africa, Southeast Asia and the Pacific Islands. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. A person returning from El Salvador diagnosed with the Zika virus in Texas2. Travelers affected by Zika virus in the U.S. since 20073. First person infected in Puerto Rico4. Zika virus symptoms5. Zika virus linked to microcephaly6. Locations of Zika virus outbreaksVOICEOVER (in English): “Texas health officials on Tuesday confirmed that a woman who had recently returned to the Houston area from El Salvador was diagnosed with the Zika virus.” “According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, since 2007 at least 22 cases of Zika have been confirmed in travelers returning to the U.S. from other countries.” “In December, Puerto Rico confirmed its first locally acquired case of Zika, suggesting the virus may now be circulating there.”“Zika is transmitted by the Aedes genus of mosquito. It causes a mild disease with fever, rash and joint pain but is rarely fatal.” “However, Brazil is investigating a possible connection between the virus and infants born with a condition known as microcephaly, an abnormally small head size associated with incomplete brain development.”“Outbreaks of the Zika virus have so far occurred in parts of Africa, Southeast Asia and the Pacific Islands.” SOURCES: Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, U.S. Centers for Disease Controlhttp://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-health-zika-idUSKCN0UQ29U20160112http://www.wsj.com/articles/houston-area-woman-diagnosed-with-mosquito-borne-zika-virus-1452628952http://www.cdc.gov/zika/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Thai-Italian woman searches for life-saving bone marrow donor
item.description: LONDON A young woman is now racing against time to find a stem cell donor after she was diagnosed with blood cancer in December. Her case has been severely complicated by the fact that she’s half Thai and half Italian. Twenty-four-year-old Lara Casalotti, a mixed-raced woman recently diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia, needs a stem cell donor with HLA markers that match hers, but as matching donors usually come from the same ethnic background, finding a match for her HLA genes has not been easy.For a stem cell transplant to be successful, there must be an HLA match. HLA are genes that encode for proteins found on all cells. The proteins act as markers that let the immune system know which cells belong to the body, and which don’t. In order to determine a match, doctors review eight types of markers: two A markers, two Bs, two Cs, two called DRB1 and sometimes two called DQ. An adult donor must match at least six of the markers.An individual inherits half of their HLA genes from their mother and the other half from their father. Therefore, siblings have a 25 percent chance of matching. Casalotti was told last week that her only brother is not a match.Now the family is launching a worldwide appeal for more donors from a minority ethnic or a mixed-race background to not only find a donor for Lara, but also to help other blood cancer patients from a minority ethnic background.
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,stem cell transplant,stem cell,stem cell donation process,stem cell donation,bone marrow donation process,blood cancer treatment,Lara Casalotti,Match4Lara,nma,next media animation,Taiwanese animators

item.title: Daily Telegraph backtracks after installing workplace monitors on journalists’ desks
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twThe Daily Telegraph made an abrupt U-turn on Monday when it removed workplace monitors from its newsroom just four hours after installing them.Journalists were surprised to find the OccupEye sensors attached to their desks and took to Googling the brand to find out what they were, BuzzFeed News reported.The paper told staff in an email the sensors were installed to monitor energy usage so it could reduce power costs, according to BuzzFeed News.But Britain’s National Union of Journalists hit out at the move, describing it as “Big Brother-style surveillance” in the newsroom, the Guardian reported.The devices are designed to help companies cut costs by reducing the number of desks in the workplace, according to the Guardian.The battery-powered, wireless sensors can be mounted on walls, ceilings, under chairs, or underneath desks and are triggered by motion and heat.The Telegraph removed the sensors after receiving negative feedback from staff about their deployment, BuzzFeed News reported.In a note to staff, the paper said it would look at alternative ways to gather “environmental sustainability” data, according to BuzzFeed News.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. OccupEye sensor being mounted underneath a desk2. Sensor monitoring the movement of a journalist at their desk3. Sensor emitting signal to receiver4. Receiver sending data to desktop PC5. Desktop PC displaying data6. Journalists discovers sensor, becomes angryVOICEOVER (in English): “The battery-powered, wireless OccupEye sensors can be mounted on walls, ceilings, under chairs, or underneath desks.”“The firm behind the system says it is discrete and allows employers to re-deploy sensors quickly and easily.” “The sensors are triggered by motion and heat. They record how a workspace is used and transfer the data to a receiver.” “Each receiver can handle data from more than 500 individual sensors. The receivers send data logs to the cloud.”“Employers can then access the data through a web browser to see exactly how much an individual workspace is used.”“The Telegraph removed the sensors after receiving negative feedback from staff about their deployment.”SOURCES: BuzzFeed News, The Guardianhttp://www.buzzfeed.com/jimwaterson/telegraph-workplace-sensors?utm_term=.yuD9Z9LV2Q#.gcyw4wGa0mhttp://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jan/11/nuj-criticises-daily-telegraph-for-monitoring-journalists-desk-time***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Robotic deer help stop illegal hunting in undercover anti-poaching stings
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twWildlife officials nationwide have been putting out mechanical decoys to catch poachers hunting illegally. The robotic animals have been effective at catching people and forcing them to think twice before they shoot. The decoys are made from taxidermied deer. The body is fitted with a radio-control system that moves the head, ears and tail independently.Wildlife officials set up the Robo-Deer by the side of the road and then wait nearby for someone to take the bait. A remote control is used to move the decoy deer and make it look more realistic.The Washington Post reports that two men in Maryland were recently caught in October after shining flashlights at a Robo-Deer and then shooting at it with crossbows. Officers found two crossbows, two flashlights, marijuana and a glass pipe in their car. Similar to other cases, charges filed against them included: having a loaded weapon in their car, shooting from the road, and shining a light at the deer. While all charges were dropped last Thursday, the Post reported, both men received a 30-day prison sentence.According to the Post, the Maryland Natural Resources Police owns not just mechanical deer, but also mechanical turkeys and bears as well. The mechanical animals are built to be shot and can withstand many “injuries,” so a single decoy can be used repeatedly. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Robo-Deer made from a taxidermied deer with a radio-control system installed inside2. Wildlife officials set up decoy and then wait nearby3. Officials can control the deer’s movements with a remote control4. Two men recently caught while shooting a decoy deer5. Poachers often charged with possession of loaded weapon and hunting from vehicleVOICEOVER (in English): “The robotic deer that help nab poachers are made from taxidermied deer. The body is fitted with a radio-control system that moves the head, ears and tail independently.”“Wildlife officials set up the Robo-Deer by the side of the road and then wait nearby for someone to take the bait.”“A remote control is used to move the decoy deer and make it look more realistic.”“In October, two men in Maryland were caught after they shot at a Robo-Deer with crossbows.”“Similar to other cases, charges filed against them included: having a loaded weapon in their car, shooting from the road, and shining a light at the deer. SOURCES: The Washington Post, Popular Science, The Humane Society of the United Stateshttps://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/hunters-caught-with-help-of-undercover-operative-robo-deer/2016/01/08/cd291250-b645-11e5-9388-466021d971de_story.htmlhttp://www.popsci.com/robodeer-catch-poachershttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=24LypesotVo***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: US deploys B-52 bomber over South Korea after North Korea’s nuclear test
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twThe United States deployed a B-52 bomber over South Korea on Sunday in a show of force after North Korea allegedly carried out a nuclear test last week.The B-52 bomber, capable of carrying nuclear weapons and based in Guam, was deployed to Osan on Sunday. The city is south of Seoul and about 62 miles from the North Korean border, Reuters reported.The bomber, flanked by a U.S. F-16 fighter jet and a South Korean F-15 fighter jet, flew low over Osan Air Base before returning to Guam.“This was a demonstration of the ironclad U.S. commitment to our allies in South Korea, in Japan, and to the defense of the American homeland,” Adm. Harry B. Harris Jr., the commander of U.S. Pacific Command said in the statement quoted by ABC News.North Korean leader Kim Jong Un said the nuclear test was a self-defence step against a U.S. threat of nuclear war and no one had the right to criticize it.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. A B-52 bomber with nuclear weapons2. Depiction of the bomber flies to Osan from Guam; distance between Osan and border3. The bomber flying in the air with a U.S. F-16 and a South Korean F-15VOICEOVER (in English): “A U.S. B-52 bomber, capable of carrying nuclear weapons..”“...based in Guam, was deployed to Osan on Sunday. The city is south of Seoul and about 62 miles from the North Korean border.”“The bomber, flanked by a U.S. F-16 fighter jet and a South Korean F-15 fighter jet, flew low over Osan Air Base before returning to Guam.”SOURCES: Reuters, ABC Newshttp://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-nuclear-idUSKCN0UN0Y420160110http://abcnews.go.com/International/us-52-flyover-south-korea-response-north-korean/story?id=36192658***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: World’s tallest evacuation chute measures 81 meters
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA Danish company has just received approval for a record-breaking 81-meter-tall evacuation chute for use on oil rigs that could help save lives in the event of a future disaster similar to the Deepwater Horizon explosion in 2010.The new escape chute, manufactured by Viking Life-Saving, is designed for oil rigs measuring up to 81 meters tall, or about the same height as the Statue of Liberty.In the event of an emergency, the chute automatically drops down to the level of the water, where a life raft inflates ready for the evacuees.The workers then slide down the chute one by one, before gathering in the life raft, where they can float away and wait to be rescued.The new chute is capable of evacuating 146 people in just 10 minutes.The manufacturer says the new chutes are in response to the ever increasing heights of new rigs, which make escape boats no longer viable.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Height comparison of offshore oil rig and Statue of Liberty2. Depiction of the escape chute and life raft deployment3. Depiction of the crew travelling down the chute4. Chute capacity (146 people evacuated in 10 minutes)VOICEOVER (in English): “The record-breaking new escape chute, manufactured by Danish company Viking Life-Saving, is designed for oil rigs measuring up to 81m, or about the same height as the Statue of Liberty.”“In the event of an emergency, the chute automatically drops down to the level of the water, where a life raft inflates ready for the evacuees.”“The workers then slide down the chute one by one, before gathering in the life raft, where they can float away and wait to be rescued.”“The new chute is capable of evacuating 146 people in just 10 minutes.”SOURCES: GCaptainhttp://gcaptain.com/2016/01/07/worlds-tallest-evacuation-chute-approved-to-81-meters-photos/#.Vo8SUpN96CS***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: North Korea’s hydrogen bomb test claim sparks scepticism
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twNorth Korea this week said it had successfully tested a miniaturized hydrogen bomb at the Punggye-ri nuclear test site, but the claim has been met by international skepticism.There are four common techniques to monitor nuclear blasts, Reuters reported, citing the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test Ban Treaty Organization (CTBTO). One of which is seismic technology, which monitors geological activity such as earthquakes. Multiple seismic monitoring stations detected a 5.1 earthquake near the test location the Punggye-ri nuclear test site. Other techniques include hydroacoustic monitoring which investigates underwater explosions, and infrasound monitoring which measures atmospheric nuclear blasts. A key verification technique is radionuclide monitoring which determines what particles and gases are left in the atmosphere. According to Reuters, verifying Pyongyang’s most recent claim of a hydrogen bomb would require the presence of tritium and lithium.“If they find lithium, then it's definitely a hydrogen bomb test, but if it's only xenon ... then you're not going to know,” Reuters quoted Shin Kyung-min, a member of South Korea's parliamentary intelligence committee as saying.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Depiction of four methods to monitor nuclear blasts2. Depiction of seismic monitoring; 5.1 earthquake detected near Punggye-ri nuclear test site3. Depiction of hydroacoustic monitoring4. Depiction of infrasound monitoring5. Depiction of radionuclide monitoring; presence of hydrogen isotope tritium in the airVOICEOVER (in English): “Experts employ four common techniques to determine if an atomic or hydrogen bomb has been tested. The first is seismic monitoring.”“Monitoring stations did detect an earthquake measuring 5.1 near Punggye-ri, the site where North Korea has previously tested atomic weapons.”“Hydroacoustic monitoring is used to investigate underwater detonations.”“While infrasound monitoring measures any atmospheric nuclear blasts.”“Another key verification technique is radionuclide monitoring. This detects what particles and gases are in the atmosphere. “Verifying Pyongyang's hydrogen bomb test claim would require the presence of Trillium and lithium in the atmosphere.”SOURCES: Reuters, New York Times, CNN, CTBTOhttp://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-nuclear-test-factbox-idUSKBN0UK2B320160106http://www.reuters.com/article/northkorea-nuclear-detection-idUSKBN0UK21B20160106http://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/07/world/asia/north-korea-hydrogen-bomb-q-a.html?_r=0http://edition.cnn.com/2016/01/06/asia/north-korea-bomb-test-key-questions/index.htmlhttps://www.ctbto.org/the-treaty/developments-after-1996/2016-dprk-announced-nuclear-test/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Lyft’s vision for an on-demand network of self-driving cars will mean fewer cars on the road
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twLyft, an American ride-hailing service, announced on Monday that General Motors has invested $500 million in the company, and the companies together plan to develop a network of autonomous vehicles.From the proposed plan, self-driving cars would reach American consumers through a ride-sharing service first rather than through individual ownership. According to a study by IHS Automotive, car ownership in the United States has crept to nearly 258 million vehicles as of 2015. Lyft and General Motors hope to change this through an on-demand network of self-driving cars. Forbes cites a Harvard Health Watch study that says the average American drives almost two hours a day. Even if self-driving cars takes up to half a day for maintenance and to recharge, that still gives users 12 hours a day to use one vehicle enough time for six Americans to use the car. If six people can use one car, this means the 258 million vehicles on the road could potentially be reduced to around 43 million, or one-sixth of 258 million. The approximately 258 million vehicles registered in the United States are not all owned by different individuals. Some people own more than one car, which means the number of hours cars are left sitting idle is probably even greater.Reuters reports that the two companies haven’t set out a deadline for when the on-demand network would be available to consumers, but would immediately offer Lyft users short term rentals of GM cars. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Number of passenger vehicles in the United States2. Average American only drives two hours a day, leaving his car idle for 22 hours3. Lots of vehicles in the United States are idle through much of the day4. Six people could use one of Lyft’s on-demand cars5. How using on-demand vehicles would cut down on number of cars total6. If carpooling was used, how this would cut down the number of cars even moreVOICEOVER (in English): “Car ownership in the U.S. had crept to nearly 258 million vehicles as of 2015. Lyft and General Motors hope to change this through an on-demand network of self-driving cars.”“The average American drives almost two hours a day and leaves his car idle for the remainder of the day.”“This potentially means that all 258 million vehicles in the U.S. could be idle for an estimated 5.67 billion hours each day.” “Even if a self-driving requires up to half a day for maintenance, that still gives users 12 hours a day to use one vehicle enough time for six Americans to use the car.” “If six people can use one car, this means the 258 million vehicles on the road could potentially be reduced to around 43 million, or one-sixth of 258 million.”“If people carpool, the amount of cars on the road becomes even less.”SOURCES: The New York Times, Reuters, IHS Automotive, Wired, Forbeshttp://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/05/technology/gm-invests-in-lyft.html?_r=1http://www.reuters.com/article/us-gm-lyft-investment-idUSKBN0UI1A820160104http://press.ihs.com/press-release/automotive/average-age-light-vehicles-us-rises-slightly-2015-115-years-ihs-reportshttp://www.wired.com/2016/01/gm-and-lyft-are-building-a-network-of-self-driving-cars/http://www.forbes.com/sites/stevenrosenbaum/2015/02/26/the-future-of-tv-is-mobile-and-not-the-way-you-think/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: U.S. repeals labeling law for pork and beef products
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twUnder country of origin labelling, or COOL, retailers are required to notify customers about the origin of certain foods. Muscle cuts of beef and pork, as well as ground beef and pork were recently removed from the program.According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, this includes muscle cuts and ground meat of lamb, goat and chicken, as well as farm-raised fish and shellfish. Fresh and frozen fruit as well as vegetables such as peanuts, pecans, macadamia nuts and ginseng are also on the COOL list. However, the U.S. Department of Agriculture recently removed muscle cuts of pork and beef and ground pork and beef from this list. The removal is the result of an international trade dispute Canada and Mexico brought against the U.S, reported Forbes.In its verdict, the World Trade Organization ruled that the United States’ labelling program discriminated against foreign livestock, reported Forbes.According to the Chicago Tribune, supporters of COOL say it encourages purchases of American meat and is safer, as consumers can know the product’s origin. Those opposed say tracking and labelling is expensive. Additionally, not repealing the law could have resulted in over US$1.1 billion in retaliatory trade tariffs being levied against the U.S, reported the Chicago Tribune.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Explanation of country of origin labelling2. Meats labelled under COOL3. Removal of pork and beef from COOL4. Map view of trade dispute5. Consumer selecting U.S. meat6. Potential retaliatory tariffs against the U.S. VOICEOVER (in English): "With country of origin labelling or COOL for short, retailers are required to notify customers about the origin of certain foods.""This includes muscle cuts, ground lamb, goat and chicken meat, as well as farm-raised fish and shellfish. Fresh and frozen fruit as well as vegetables such as peanuts, pecans, macadamia nuts and ginseng are also on the COOL list.""But, the U.S. Department of Agriculture recently removed muscle cuts of pork and beef and ground pork and beef from this list.""The removal is the result of an international trade dispute Canada and Mexico brought against the U.S.""In its verdict, the World Trade Organization ruled that the United States’ labelling program discriminated against foreign livestock and violated international trade regulations.""Supporters of food source labelling say it encourages purchases of American-bred meat and is safer, as consumers can know a product’s origin.""Those opposed say tracking and labelling is prohibitively expensive. Additionally, not repealing the law could have resulted in over a US$1.1 billion in retaliatory trade tariffs being levied against the U.S."SOURCES: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Chicago Tribune, World Trade Organization, Forbes, Merritt Herald, Reutershttp://www.ams.usda.gov/rules-regulations/coolhttp://www.chicagotribune.com/dining/ct-cool-country-origin-labeling-food-1223-20160104-story.htmlhttps://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/dispu_e/cases_e/1pagesum_e/ds384sum_e.pdfhttp://www.forbes.com/sites/nancyhuehnergarth/2015/12/21/quashing-consumers-right-to-know-congress-repeals-country-of-origin-labeling-for-beef-and-pork/http://www.merrittherald.com/1b-retaliatory-sanctions-approved-by-wto/http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-congress-fiscal-canada-idUSKBN0TZ2T420151216***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Australia surfers quit jobs to create ‘Seabin’ to clean up marinas and reduce ocean pollution
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twTwo Australia surfers are gaining the attention from investors around the world for their invention of a device that helps clean the ocean, according to Australia’s ABC News.ABC News reports that Andrew Turton and Pete Ceglinski, who are best friends, became frustrated over the amount of trash that was floating in the ocean. They decided to quit their jobs to come up with a sustainable solution to the problem of ocean pollution, and invented the Seabin.The Seabin is an automated rubbish bin designed to be mounted on marina docks to help clean the water. According to the duo’s company website, the Seabin, which is built from recycled materials, is mounted to a dock and connected to water pump that is powered by an source on the shore.The pump pulls water through the Seabin, thus bringing all the floating rubbish and debris in the water into a natural fibre bag inside the device before water is pumped back out. The floating debris is captured inside the Seabin, and water flows out through the bottom of the bin and pulled up into the pump on the dock. There is also an option to attach an oil and water separating device to the water pump to clean the water before it is returned to the ocean."It essentially works as a similar concept to a skimmer box from your pool filter. But it's designed on a scale to work and essentially attract all that rubbish within a location within a marine harbour," said Seabin spokesperson Richard Talmage, as quoted by ABC News.ABC News reports that the duo designed a prototype of the bin in Perth before taking it to market in Mallorca in Spain, a marina capital of Europe. A crowdfunding effort has already raised $50,000 for commercial production of the Seabin, and a video of the device has attracted more than 10 million hits online.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Seabin created from recyclable materials2. Water and trash being pumped through the Seabin3. Water filtered and returned to the ocena4. Seabin catch bag being changedVOICEOVER (in English): “Built from recycled materials, the Seabin is fixed to a dock with a water pump that runs on shore power. The pump brings water through the Seabin, which allows the natural fibre bag inside the device to catch floating rubbish and debris before water is pumped back out.”“Users have the option of installing an oil and water separator to the pump to clean the water that flows through it before the water is allowed to flow back into the ocean.”“The Seabin is lined with a natural fiber ‘catch bag’ that collects floating debris. When the bag is full, it can changed with another clean one, and the collected debris can be disposed of responsibly.” SOURCES:Seabin Project, ABC News Australiahttp://www.seabinproject.com/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-12-20/seabin-designed-by-australian-surfers-to-start-cleaning-up-ocean/7044174***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Astronomers believe giant comets ‘centaurs’ might pose danger to life on Earth
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twAstronomers from Armagh Observatory and the University of Buckingham, writing in the journal Astronomy and Geophysics, say giant comets in our solar system could pose a bigger hazard to life on Earth than asteroids. NASA tracks around 12,992 near-Earth objects orbiting within our solar system. The agency estimates that around 1,607 of them are “potentially hazardous asteroids,” Tech Times reports.But a greater threat may be posed by giant comets called “centaurs,” balls of ice and dust about 50 to 100 kilometres wide and with unstable elliptical orbits that start beyond Neptune.According to the team of astronomers including professors Bill Napier, Duncan Steel, and Mark Bailey and Dr. David Asher, while orbiting, centaurs cross the orbits of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune. Occasionally, one will be deflected by the gravity fields of one of these planets and be pushed towards the Earth instead.If these comets get closer to the Earth, and therefore to the Sun, they begin to disintegrate. At that point their debris will, according to the astronomers, inevitably hit our planet. The disintegration of giant comets would produce intermittent debris bombardments lasting up to 100,000 years. “A centaur arrival carries the risk of injecting, into the atmosphere ... a mass of dust and smoke comparable to that assumed in nuclear winter studies,” the researchers wrote, referring to the climate effects provoked by firestorms that would be caused by a nuclear war. The study notes that a comet’s disintegration and impact on Earth may have caused mass extinction events in the past, such as the extinction of the dinosaurs 65 million years ago.The researchers also wrote that, based on growing scientific knowledge of near-Earth space, incidents of environmental upheaval and interruptions in the progress of ancient civilizations also suggest the arrival of a centaur 30,000 years ago.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Amount of objects near-Earth and amount of Potentially Hazardous Asteroids2. Centaurs width and orbits3. Centaurs crossing paths with Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune4. One comet rebounding off the gravity fields of one of the planets and being pushed towards the Earth instead5. Comets getting closer to the Earth, disintegrating and about to hit it6. Debris bombardment lasting for 100,000 years VOICEOVER (in English): Astronomers believe giant comets could wipe out life on Earth“NASA tracks around 12,992 near-Earth objects orbiting within our solar system. The agency estimates that around 1,607 of them are ‘potentially hazardous asteroids.’”“But a greater threat may be posed by what are called 'centaurs,' balls of ice and dust about 50 to 100 kilometres wide with unstable elliptical orbits that start beyond Neptune.”“While orbiting, these giant comets cross paths with the orbits of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune.”“Occasionally, one will be deflected by the gravity fields of one of these planets and be pushed towards the Earth.”“If these comets get closer to the Earth, and therefore to the Sun, they begin to disintegrate. At that point their debris will, according to the astronomers, inevitably hit our planet.”“The disintegration of giant comets would produce intermittent debris bombardments lasting up to 100,000 years.” SOURCES: Royal Astronomical Society, International Business Times, Tech Times, Phys.orghttps://www.ras.org.uk/news-and-press/2758-giant-comets-could-pose-danger-to-life-on-earthhttp://www.ibtimes.com.au/astronomers-warn-giant-comets-bigger-asteroids-could-hit-destroy-earth-1495304http://www.techtimes.com/articles/118911/20151223/newly-discovered-giant-comets-threaten-life-on-earth-astronomers.htmhttp://phys.org/news/2015-12-giant-comets-threaten-earth-astronomers.html***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas an
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,comets,comets hitting earth,astronomers,giant comets,centaurs,wipe out life on earth,life on earth,university of buckingham,nma,next media animation,taiwanese animators

item.title: SpaceX celebrates rocket’s first historic vertical landing
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twSpaceX, the company owned by high-tech entrepreneur and billionaire Elon Musk, has for the first time landed vertically an unmanned rocket. A previous attempt in June ended in failure when one of the company’s Falcon 9 rockets exploded after takeoff. The 68.4-meter-tall upgraded Falcon 9 took off from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station on Monday with 11 Orbcomm satellites on board, the Guardian reported. Once in space, the booster separated from the Dragon capsule and deployed all of the satellites it was carrying. The satellites will provide machine-to-machine messaging services on the ground.The booster reached a distance of 200 kilometers above the Earth and stayed in space for about 10 minutes before heading back to a landing site about 9.65 kilometers south of its launch pad, the BBC reported. “Welcome back, baby!” Musk wrote on Twitter while on his way to the landing zone.A standard SpaceX rocket launch costs $61.2 million. According to Bloomberg, Musk estimated that landing rockets upright and making them reusable would cut costs by a hundredfold. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket2. Falcon 9 launch3. Falcon 9 rocket in space releasing 11 satellites4. Falcon 9 rocket’s distance from Earth and time spent in space before returning to Earth5. item.title: ModiFace Live app allows users to virtually apply makeup in real time
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.tw Animation: Next Media AnimationVideo: Theresa Chong, Next Media Animation ModiFace Live is an augmented reality beauty app that uses face tracking and gesture tracking technology. The app allows users to virtually apply makeup in real time and record a video of their different looks. According to ModiFace Founder and CEO, Parham Aarabi, developing a makeup app was an accident. “The initial idea was for defense applications for lip reading,” says Aarabi. “Then, as a fun thing on the side, we decided to put this, a version of this, for changing your lips online. But, that became very popular and told us that there’s a lot of interest in something like this.” The newest ModiFace Live app automatically tracks a user's’ face because the system has already learned numerous facial features. According to Aarabi, over the past eight years, users had to upload their photos and manually define the shape of their eyes, eyebrows and lips by adjusting points on their photos. After one hundred million photos, the system learned how to recognize these facial patterns. The app also tracks gestures, such as a pouting lip or a raised eyebrow, because it compares facial movements relative to each other. Based on the gesture, the app suggests different makeup applications. Someone with a critical eye may be wondering why users would even want an augmented reality app for applying makeup. “People have always been interested in trying different effects on their own photo,” says Aarabi. “The selfie phenomenon of applying different things on your image has been very popular. But, we believe it’s even more popular when it’s instant and easy to access, and when it relates to videos.” Aarabi says they’ll be launching a medical version of the ModiFace Live app in 2016. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. ModiFace Live app2. Parham Aarabi interview3. Animation explaining how the app uses face tracking and gesture tracking technology4. ModiFace Live skepticism5. Parham Aarabi interview6. Medical version of ModiFace Live app VOICEOVER (in English): ModiFace Live is an augmented reality beauty app that uses face tracking and gesture tracking technology. The app allows users to virtually apply makeup in real time and record a video of their different looks. According to ModiFace Founder and CEO, Parham Aarabi, developing a makeup app was an accident.The initial idea was for defense applications for lip reading. Then, as a fun thing on the side, we decided to put this, a version of this, for changing your lips online. But, that became very popular and told us that there’s a lot of interest in something like this.The newest ModiFace Live app automatically tracks a user's face because the system has already learned numerous facial features.According to Aarabi, over the past eight years, users had to upload their photos and manually define the shapes of their eyes, eyebrows and lips by adjusting points on their photos.After one hundred million photos, the system learned how to recognize these facial patterns.The app also tracks gestures, such as a pouting lip or a raised eyebrow, because it compares facial movements relative to each other.Based on the gesture, the app suggests different makeup applications. Someone with a critical eye may be wondering why users would even want an augmented reality app for applying makeup.People have always been interested in trying different effects on their own photo. The selfie phenomenon of applying different things on your image has been very popular. But, we believe it’s even more popular when it’s instant and easy to access, and when it relates to videos.Aarabi says they’ll be launching a medical version of the ModiFace Live app in 2016. item.title: Wearable energy generator uses urine to power wireless transmitter
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twUrine could become an alternative energy source to fossil fuels, according to the inventors of socks which use waste fluid to create electricity. The wearable technology can generate enough electricity to power a wireless transmitter, researchers at the University of West England (UWE) said in a press release. Soft tubes placed under the heels of the footwear ensure that urine keeps being pumped while a person is walking. The pumped urine passes over microbial fuel cells (MFCs), which are energy generators located inside the footwear’s material support.The MFCs contain bacteria capable of eating the urine and breaking it down, producing electrons in the process.The electricity created is then able to power a wireless transmitter that sends a signal to a computer. The invention was inspired by the simple cardiovascular system of fish, the researchers said.The technology can use any organic waste to produce electricity, and could be an alternative to fossil fuels, according to the UWE press release.The invention also opens up the possibility to use waste to power portable and wearable devices, according to Ioannis Ieropoulos, from the Bristol BioEnergy Center at UWE.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. The urine-powered socks system functioning like a fish cardiovascular system 2. Urine passing through the footwear soft tubes while person is walking3. The urine passing over microbial fuel cells (MFC) inside the material support4. The bacteria inside the MFC producing electricity from urine5. The electricity produced by MFC charging a wireless transmitter, which sends signal to a computer6. Container storing urineVOICEOVER (in English): "The urine-powered footwear design was inspired by the simple cardiovascular system of fish." "Soft tubes under the heels pump urine while a person is walking," "circulating the urine over microbial fuel cells embedded in the socks.""The microbial fuel cells contain bacteria that consume organic waste. The fuel cells convert energy produced by microbial growth into electricity.""The electricity generated by the socks can power a wireless transmitter that sends a signal to a computer.""The system comes with a container that can store up to 648 millilitres of urine."SOURCES: University of the West England, IOP Sciencehttp://info.uwe.ac.uk/news/UWENews/news.aspx?id=3246http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-3190/11/1/016001***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Shape-shifting robots are designed for space exploration
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twAnimation: Next Media AnimationVideo: Theresa Chong, Next Media AnimationResearchers at UC Berkeley are developing shape-shifting robots for space exploration. “It will be ridiculously inexpensive compared to the current rovers,” says Alice Agogino, a mechanical engineering professor at UC Berkeley. “We hope it will be more robust, will be faster, and will be able to handle more complicated terrains. Also known as a six-bar tensegrity structure, these spherical-shaped robots roll along surfaces by shifting their center of gravity. “They have either compressive elements that are rods, or they have elastic elements, which are kind of like rubber bands,” Agogino says. “And, they shift their shape by pulling on the elastic elements and making them longer or shorter allowing them to take on a range of different shapes and thus, change of gravity. One of the shape-shifting shapes that we’re interested in is for them to be flat. So that in storage, in a rover, or in a spacecraft, they can be flat and then they can spring open and then be launched.” Agogino says their target mission is either the moon or Titan, which one of Saturn’s moons. In addition to space exploration, researchers are also finding ways to use these robots on earth. “We’re also exploring applications where in fact the aircraft itself might be a tensegrity structure that can fly through the air, drop on the ground, and actually conduct some kind of search and rescue, or, delivery of emergency supplies,” Agogino explains. Although the first robot prototype was built with Legos, the latest version has been upgraded with aluminum rods and 3-D printed parts. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Shape-shifting robots2. Alice Agogino interview3. Shape-shifting robots4. Animation explaining how the robots move by shifting its shape. Voiceover by Alice Agogino.5. Robot’s target mission6. Applications of robot on earth7. Robot materials VOICEOVER (in English): These robots can change their shapes to do this… Alice Agogino is a mechanical engineering professor at UC Berkeley. Agogino and her team of researchers are trying to revolutionize space exploration with their research.It will be ridiculously inexpensive compared to the current rovers. We hope it will be more robust, will be faster, and will be able to handle more complicated terrains.Also known as a six-bar tensegrity structure, these spherical-shaped robots roll along surfaces by shifting their center of gravity.They have either compressive elements that are rods, or they have elastic elements, which are kind of like rubber bands.And, they shift their shape by pulling on the elastic elements and making them longer or shorter allowing them to take on a range of different shapes and, thus, change of gravity.One of the shape-shifting shapes that we’re interested in is for them to be flat.So that in storage, in a rover, or in a spacecraft, they can be flat and then they can spring open and then be launched.Agogino says their target mission is either the moon or Titan, which is one of Saturn’s moons. In addition to space exploration, researchers are also finding ways to use these robots on earth. We’re also exploring applications where in fact the aircraft itself might be a tensegrity structure that can fly through the air, drop on the ground, and actually conduct some kind of search and rescue, or, delivery of emergency supplies.Although the first robot prototype was built with Legos, the latest version has been upgraded with aluminum rods and 3-D printed parts. SOURCES: Berkeley Emergent Space Tensegrities Robotics (BEST) Lab http://best.berkeley.edu/best-research/best-berkeley-emergent-space-tensegrities-robotics/ ***2For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: China oil company Sinopec building gas station on Woody Island in disputed South China sea
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twChinese oil company Sinopec is building a service station in the disputed Paracels Islands in the South China Sea, Reuters reported. The station, along with a storage tank, is being built on Woody Island and will be completed in one year. The facilities will provide fuel to all Chinese-controlled islands and reefs in the South China Sea over the next few years, Sinopec said in a post on its microblog. Woody Island has a population of about 1,000 people. China has also been expanding infrastructure on it by building a new airport facility and extending the runway.China claims nearly all of the South China Sea, through which more than $5 trillion worth of maritime trade passes every year. That claim is not recognized by the United States and its allies, which conduct freedom of navigation exercises in waters claimed by China.Other countries have claims in the South China Sea such as Brunei, Vietnam, Malaysia, the Philippines and Taiwan. On November 25, the BBC recorded a Royal Australian Air Force P-3 Orion surveillance plane conducting one such patrol. The plane tried to inform the Chinese navy, which did not respond. According to the Sydney Morning Herald, by stepping up military surveillance flights over the region, Australia is showing China it does not intend to stop operations in the disputed areas.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. A filling station and storage tank built in one year on Woody island 2. The station providing fuel for Chinese-controlled islands in the South China sea 3. Infrastructure expansion on Woody island 4. South China sea maritime trade and China’s claims 5. Australian Air Force surveillance plane over the South China Sea6. Pilot contacting the Chinese NavyVOICEOVER (in English): Chinese oil company building filling station on disputed island in the South China Sea“The station, along with a storage tank, is being built on Woody Island and will be completed in one year.” “The facilities will provide fuel to all Chinese-controlled islands and reefs in the South China Sea over the next few years, Sinopec said in a post on its microblog.” “China has also been expanding infrastructure on Woody Island by building a new airport facility and extending the runway.”“China claims nearly all of the South China Sea, through which more than $5 trillion worth of maritime trade passes every year.”“That claim is not recognized by the United States and its allies, which conduct freedom of navigation exercises in waters claimed by China.”“The BBC recorded a Royal Australian Air Force P-3 Orion surveillance plane conducting one such patrol on Nov. 25. The plane tried to inform the Chinese navy, which did not respond.”SOURCES: Reuters, ABC News, Sydney Morning Heraldhttp://www.reuters.com/article/us-southchinasea-china-sinopec-idUSKBN0TX0D420151214http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-12-15/audio-captures-raaf-challenging-chinese-navy-in-south-china-sea/7030076http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/south-china-sea-australia-steps-up-air-patrols-in-defiance-of-beijing-20151215-gloc2e.html***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Plans for City of London’s tallest building unveiled
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twPlans have been unveiled for the construction of the tallest building in the City of London, the financial district of the United Kingdom’s capital.The 73-floor skyscraper, called 1 Undershaft, will rise to 309.6 metres, which is the same height as the current tallest building in London, the Shard. The building is intended to provide quality office space, CNN reported.“1 Undershaft represents the very best of British architecture in a premier location at the heart of London. It will be a building where the public are put first with a new public square at its base and the capital's tallest free public viewing gallery at its top,” Architect Eric Parry, whose company designed the building, told CNN.The official completion date of the building has not been announced yet. According to CNN, it is believed that the building will be put to use within the next decade.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Location of 1 Undershaft2. Depiction of the building has office space, public viewing gallery, restaurant and public space3. Depiction of 1 Undershaft will rise to the same height as the Shard VOICEOVER (in English): “A skyscraper to be named 1 Undershaft, will become one of the tallest buildings in the historic center known as the City of London, which is north of the River Thames.”“The 73-floor structure is intended to provide office space. It will host a public viewing gallery and restaurant at the top of the building, and a public space at the bottom.”“The building faces London’s current tallest building, the Shard across the river. Developers say the building will rise to the same height as the Shard, at 309.6 metres.”SOURCES: CNN, The Guardianhttp://edition.cnn.com/2015/12/08/architecture/london-tallest-building-city-undershaft/index.htmlhttp://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/architecture-design-blog/2015/dec/07/1-undershaft-tallest-skyscraper-city-of-london-eric-parry***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Hoverboards grounded by several U.S. airlines due to fire risk
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twHoverboards are fast becoming one of most wanted items this Christmas, but due to safety fears the devices have been banned by several airlines.According to Reuters, passengers will no longer be able to carry hoverboards in their carry on or checked baggage on flights from Delta Airlines, American Airlines and United Airlines. The devices are also known self balancing scooters, or swegways.Reports indicate that some hoverboards have caught on fire or have exploded due to overcharged lithium-ion batteries. Airlines fear that hoverboards may pose a fire risk while onboard an aircraft, Reuters reported.In the UK, authorities found that 88% of 17,000 hoverboards examined at British entry points were unsafe and at risk of overheating, exploding or catching on fire, Reuters reported. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Airlines that have prohibited hoverboards2. Baggage3. Hoverboard overcharging4. Hoverboard on a plane5. Hoverboard risk in the UKVOICEOVER (in English): "Hoverboards are fast becoming one of most wanted items this Christmas, but due to safety fears the devices have been banned by several airlines...""...meaning, passengers will no longer be able to carry the devices in their carry-on or checked luggage.""Reports indicate that some hoverboards have caught on fire or have exploded due to overcharged lithium-ion batteries.""And because of this, airlines fear the gadgets could pose a potential risk while onboard an aircraft."SOURCES: Reuters, Washington Post, ABC News, NBC News, New York Daily News, http://www.reuters.com/article/us-airlines-safety-hoverboards-idUSKBN0TT2DW20151210https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/innovations/wp/2015/12/10/airlines-are-banning-hoverboards-after-fires-trigger-safety-concerns/http://abcnews.go.com/US/delta-air-lines-banned-hoverboards/story?id=35699893http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/gadgets/u-s-safety-regulators-step-probe-hoverboards-over-fire-risk-n477896?cid=sm_tw&hootPostID=30720f0a0ba93106e52fe6d4bb2b65dfhttp://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/delta-airlines-grounds-hoverboards-article-1.2461961***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
