item.title: Gene-edited immune cells clear baby’s ‘incurable’ leukemia
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA baby girl in Britain suffering from leukemia has become the first person in the world to receive an experimental gene editing procedure that miraculously reversed her cancer.According to CBS News, Layla Richards had been diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) when she was just 14-week-old. Layla’s family was losing hope after several failed treatments, until a team of doctors at London’s Great Ormond Street Hospital performed an experimental gene editing procedure on her that saved her life.This technology is known as TALEN, which had only been previously tested on mice. It uses molecular tools that act like scissors to cut specific genes in order to make the T-cells from healthy donors to behave in two specific ways: first, the cells are able to become invisible to a powerful leukemia drug that would normally kill them; second, they are reprogrammed to target and fight against leukemia cells only.Layla spent several months in isolation due to her extremely weak immune system after the procedure. After the leukemia cells were confirmed to have been eliminated from Layla’s body, she was given a bone marrow transplant to replace her entire blood and immune system, CBS News reported.The treatment was prepared by scientists at London’s Great Ormond Street Hospital, University College London and French biotech company Cellectis. Cellectis is going to fund full clinical trials of the therapy starting next year, Reuters reported.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Layla Richards has Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia2. How healthy blood cells develop3. Blood cell development in Leukemia patients4. Leukemia cells taking up more space than healthy blood cells in blood5. Doctors in London performing the procedure on a mouse6. The gene-editing procedure7. T-cells becoming invisible to Leukemia drugs8. T-cells destroying Leukemia cells9. Layla in isolation for months after the procedure10. Layla is cleared of cancer cells; she receives bone marrow transplantVOICEOVER (in English): “Layla Richards was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia when she was just 14-week-old, a disease in which the bone marrow makes too many immature lymphocytes. This is the most common type of cancer in children.”“In a healthy child, the bone marrow makes blood stem cells that can become myeloid stem cells or lymphoid stem cells, which then develop into mature red blood cells, platelets and white blood cells.”“However, in a child with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia, too many stem cells develop into lymphoblasts, B lymphocytes or T lymphocytes, which are in fact leukemia cells.”“The leukemia cells are not able to fight infection and they take up the space for healthy blood cells in the blood and bone marrow. This may lead to infection, anemia and easy bleeding.”“Doctors in London performed a new gene-editing technology known as TALEN on Layla, which had previously only been tested on mice.”“The technology uses molecular tools that act like scissors to cut specific genes in order to make the T-cells from healthy donors behave in two specific ways.”“First, the cells are able to become invisible to a powerful leukemia drug that would normally kill them.”“Second, they are reprogrammed to target and fight against leukemia cells only.”“Layla spent several months in isolation due to her extremely weak immune system after the procedure.”“After the leukemia cells were confirmed to have been eliminated from Layla’s body, she was given a bone marrow transplant to replace her entire blood and immune system.”SOURCES: CBS News, Reuters, U.S. National Cancer Institutehttp://www.cbsnews.com/news/first-of-its-kind-designer-immune-cells-cure-babys-leukemia/http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/06/us-health-leukaemia-cellectis-idUSKCN0SU2PO20151106#doD0MpZoHffm8mGV.97http://www.cancer.gov/types/leukemia/patient/child-all-treatment-pdq

item.title: Dam collapse triggers toxic mudslide, dozens killed
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twDozens are feared dead after a dam holding back waste water from an iron ore mine in rural Brazil broke, spilling toxic mud into a town.The New York Times reports that homes and vehicles in the small mining town of Mariana in Minas Gerais were smothered in thick rivers of toxic mud on Thursday after a dam collapse around 4:20 p.m. sent industrial effluent four miles down the mountain. More than 600 people from the nearby town of Bento Rodrigues had to be evacuated as a result.The dam, owned by Brazilian Samarco -- a joint venture between iron ore miners Vale of Brazil and Australia's BHP -- ruptured for unknown reasons.The surface area of the spillage -- mining waste made up of metal fillings, water, and chemicals -- was equivalent to 10 football fields, according to AFP.At least 17 were killed in the disaster, with more than 50 injured. Reuters reports that 45 others still missing.Search and rescue efforts are ongoing, but teams are hampered by the lack of electricity and difficulty in accessing affected areas. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Brazil on map2. Dam burst, town evacuated3. Amount of mud in dam4. No. of dead, injured, missingVOICEOVER (in English): “Homes and vehicles in a mining town in southeastern Brazil were smothered in thick rivers of toxic mud on Thursday...”“...after a dam collapse around 4:20 p.m. sent industrial sludge four miles down the mountain, affecting more than 600 people from the nearby town of Bento Rodrigues.”“The surface area of the spillage -- mining waste made up of metal fillings, water, and chemicals -- was equivalent to 10 football fields.”“At least 17 were killed in the disaster, with more than 50 injured, and 45 others still missing.”SOURCES: Reuters, BBC, Wall Street Journal, Bloomberg, New York Times, AFP (via Yahoo), Voice of Americahttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/06/vale-sa-bhp-billiton-dam-idUSL1N1303CA20151106#PjpPQALbKLicUldo.97http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-34742272http://www.wsj.com/articles/mining-company-samarcos-dam-bursts-in-brazil-1446763579http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-05/samarco-says-dam-in-brazil-burst-teams-are-working-on-sitehttp://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/11/05/world/americas/ap-lt-brazil-dam-bursts.html?_r=0http://news.yahoo.com/least-17-dead-dam-bursts-brazil-mining-waste-022224741.htmlhttp://www.voanews.com/content/brazilian-dam-bursts-engulfing-town-red-sludge/3041521.html***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: White House has plan to counter catastrophic solar storms
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twNo internet. No mobile phones. No electricity to power refrigerators, run the vacuum cleaner or keep the lights on. No respite for weeks or possibly months. No Netflix. This is what would happen should a massive solar storm hit Earth, the threat of which the White House is taking seriously.In October, the White House published a 19-page paper outlining preparations and responses to massive solar electromagnetic pulses (EMP) that could potentially cripple key infrastructure.Dubbed the “National Space Weather Strategy,” the document calls for more studies on potential effects of space weather on power grids; more research to better model and predict space weather; and more cooperation among scientists and agencies at the international level, among other proposals.Scientists for years have warned of the potential dangers of solar EMPs. In 2013, insurance company Lloyd’s of London estimated the economic fallout as high as $2.6 trillion should a massive storm hit.Space weather can be traced to coronal mass ejections, or huge bursts of gas most often associated with solar flares. These solar storms send huge quantities of electromagnetic radiation toward Earth. That’s not good for power grids. A solar EMP could take entire power grids offline, plunging the world into darkness. In 1859, one of the biggest solar storms ever recorded hit Earth, in what scientists now call the Carrington event. Society before the start of the Civil War didn’t depend on electricity as we do today. So the impact was limited to disrupted telegraph lines and shocked telegraph operators. But the world today wouldn’t get off so easy. In 1989, a much smaller solar storm caused the collapse of Hydro-Quebec’s electricity transmission system, resulting in a nine-hour power outage.In 2012, we got lucky. Scientists observed a solar storm believed to be as big the Carrington event. Fortunately, because the sun rotates on its own axis, Earth was facing away from the storm and missed it by about nine days.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Depiction of coronal mass ejection2. Electromagnetic radiation hitting Earth3. Power grids and electricity shutting down4. Depiction of Carrington event5. Depiction of 1989 solar storm6. Depiction of 2012 solar storm7. Depiction of White House proposals VOICEOVER (in English): “So-called space weather events can be traced to coronal mass ejections, or huge bursts of gas most often associated with solar flares.”“These solar storms send huge quantities of electromagnetic radiation toward the earth.”“That’s not good for power grids. A solar electromagnetic pulse, or EMP, could take entire power grids offline, plunging the world into darkness.”“In 1859, one of the biggest solar storms ever recorded, the Carrington Event, hit the earth. It disrupted telegraph systems and shocked telegraph operators.”“A much smaller solar storm in 1989 caused the collapse of Hydro-Quebec’s electricity transmission system, resulting in a nine-hour power outage.”“In 2012, scientists observed a solar storm believed to be as big the Carrington Event. Fortunately, it missed earth by about nine days.”“The US is preparing for the next large solar EMP. It’s studying potential effects of space weather on power grids, backing research to better model and predict space weather, and calling for greater cooperation among scientists and agencies at the international level.” SOURCES: https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/microsites/ostp/final_nationalspaceweatherstrategy_20151028.pdf***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,solar storms,space weather,solar electromagnetic pulses,EMP,coronal mass ejections,nma,next media animation,Taiwanese animators

item.title: Workers find skeletons, coffins in burial vaults under Washington Square Park
item.description: Dozens of skeletal remains were unearthed in the Big Apple just days after Halloween near an area that used to be a public burial ground.According to Fox 5, contractors for the New York City Department of Design and Construction were digging to replace water mains near Washington Square Park earlier this week when they discovered crypts containing human remains three feet beneath the ground.Two 15-by-20 foot burial vaults were discovered side-by-side, each with a wooden door and about 8 feet deep. One crypt contained the skeletal remains of about 9 to 12 people, while the other had wooden coffins stacked one on top of the other, reports the New York Post.Both are believed to date back to the late 18th or early 19th century, and was likely part of a cemetery that may have belonged to one of two Presbyterian churches that stood in the area.Archaeologists working with the city are investigating the vaults and will be focusing on identifying those buried. Engineers are planning a new route for the water main project in order to avoid disturbing the burial grounds, reports NBC.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Washington square park on map2. Construction ongoing3. 19th century New York4. Burial vaults5. Archaeologists studying skeletonsVOICEOVER (in English): “New York City workers were carrying out construction to replace water mains near Washington Square park earlier this week...”“...when they discovered crypts containing human remains three feet beneath the ground.”“Two 15-by-20-foot burial vaults were discovered side-by-side, each about 8 feet deep, with wooden doors.”“One crypt contained the skeletal remains of about nine to 12 people, while the other had wooden coffins stacked together.”“Both date back to the late 18th or early 19th century, and were possibly part of a Presbyterian church cemetery.”“Archaeologists working with the city are now focusing on identifying each of the skeletons.”SOURCES: New York Post, Pix11 News, CNN, Fox 5, NBC New Yorkhttp://nypost.com/2015/11/05/vault-full-of-skeletons-found-under-washington-square-park/http://pix11.com/2015/11/04/old-burial-vault-human-bones-found-beneath-greenwich-village-park/http://edition.cnn.com/videos/world/2015/10/27/ancient-greek-warrior-tomb-discovered-orig.cnn/video/playlists/ancient-discoveries/http://www.fox5ny.com/news/44849964-storyhttp://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Old-Burial-Vault-Found-Beneath-Greenwich-Village-Park--340589992.html***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: France to deploy largest warship against Islamic State in Iraq and Syria
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFrance is set to deploy its largest warship to aid in the US-led coalition against Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the French president’s office said in a statement issued on Thursday after a defense cabinet meeting.France will deploy the Charles de Gaulle, a 860-foot-long French carrier that can carry up to 40 aircraft and support 100 flights a day. The carrier is usually accompanied by an attack submarine, several frigates, refuelling ships, as well as fighter jets and surveillance aircraft, reported Reuters. The warship has two aircraft strips for taking-off in the front and one for landing in the back, according to Business Insider. The ship will reportedly reduce the time it takes for French jets to carry out airstrikes, reported BBC. The French is currently using six Mirage jets stationed in Jordan and six Rafale jets in the United Arab Emirates to carry out airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq. France has carried out 271 airstrikes in 1,285 aerial missions in Iraq and two known airstrikes in Syria since September 2014, according to Agence France-Presse.The warship, the only one of its kind in France’s fleet, is usually joined with attack submarine, frigates ships, refueling ships, fighter jets and surveillance aircraft, Reuters reported. It is also the only nuclear-powered aircraft carrier outside the United States. This is the second time the ship will be deployed against ISIS, the ship was previously stationed in the Persian Gulf and used as a base for French jets from February to April, BBC reported.The French have declared the airstrikes as self defense after an IS militant killed 17 people in Paris in the beginning of the year.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. French jets in Jordan and UAE2. France carries out airstrikes against Iraq and Syria3. The Charles de Gaulle aircraft carrier4. The ship deployed to Persian Gulf in February to AprilVOICEOVER (in English): “France is currently using six Mirage jets stationed in Jordan and six Rafale jets in the United Arab Emirates to carry out airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq.”“France has carried out 271 airstrikes in Iraq and two known airstrikes in Syria since September 2014.”“France will deploy the Charles de Gaulle, a 860-foot-long French carrier that can carry up to 40 aircraft, to reduce airstrike flight time.”“The only ship of its kind was previously stationed in the Persian Gulf from February to April of this year.”SOURCES: http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34738177https://www.rt.com/news/320940-france-aircraft-carrier-is/http://www.ibtimes.com/fight-against-isis-france-deploys-charles-de-gaulle-aircraft-carrier-syria-iraq-fight-2171854http://www.naval-technology.com/projects/gaulle/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Italy purchase of arms for Reaper drones approved by U.S. State Department
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twTwo U.S. officials have told Reuters that the U.S. government has vetted and approved Italy’s request to buy armaments for their U.S. made drone aircraft. Italy first requested to buy armaments for its two U.S. made MQ-9 Reaper drones in 2012. According to the officials, the U.S. State Department has approved the sale to Italy of 156 AGM-113R2 Hellfire II missiles, 20 GBU-12 laser-guided bombs, 30 GBU-38 Joint Direct Attack Munitions, and others. Italy would be the second country after the United Kingdom to receive approval to buy armaments for it’s large U.S. made drones. In February 2015, the U.S. government enacted a new export policy governing the sale of large drones, such as the MQ-9 Reaper, and drone armaments, requiring that buyers undergo review by the U.S. State Department. Under the policy, buyers of military drones must agree not to use the drones for unlawful surveillance and may not use the drones to crack down on their domestic populations. Speaking of the government's approval of Italy’s request, one official told Reuters, "It's not a decision we've taken lightly, and it's symbolic of our trust in Italy as a partner." "Italy is a responsible member of the international community and they have been with us in every significant recent NATO and U.S.-led operation." The arms sale to Italy is valued at $129.6 million dollars, with defense contractor General Atomics acting as prime contractor. The U.S. Congress has 15 days to veto the sale of drone armaments to Italy, but is expected to allow the sale to proceed. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Italian unarmed MQ-9 Reaper drone2. List and quantity of arms to be sold3. UK receiving arms for drones first, then Italy4. Italy cannot use drone for illegal surveillance 5. Italy cannot use drone for crackdown on population6. Total value of arms sale $129.6 millionVOICEOVER (in English): "Italy requested to buy armaments for its two U.S. made MQ-9 Reaper drones in 2012." "Today, the U.S. State Department has approved the sale to Italy of 156 AGM-113R2 Hellfire II missiles, 20 GBU-12 laser-guided bombs, 30 GBU-38 Joint Direct Attack Munitions, and others." "Italy would be the second country after the United Kingdom to receive approval to buy armaments for it’s large U.S. made drones." "Under U.S. export policy, buyers of military drones must agree not to use the drones for unlawful surveillance and may not use the drones to crack down on their domestic populations." "The arms sale to Italy is valued at $129.6 million dollars." SOURCES: Reutershttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/04/us-italy-usa-drones-idUSKCN0ST1VI20151104#vyOgzGmVTlGdLTk6.97***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: FCC investigates Chinese covert radio company in the U.S.
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA special investigative report by Reuters showed that the Federal Communications Commission and the Justice Department is conducting a federal investigation on a California radio company that is reportedly backed by a subsidiary of the Chinese government. Reuters reports that G&E Studio Inc., a Los Angeles-based company, is 60 percent owned by a subsidiary of China Radio International, a Chinese state-run broadcaster based in Beijing. The California radio firm is owned by James Su, a naturalized U.S. citizen born in Shanghai.The FCC monitors indecency and political advertising in news content but otherwise does not restrict content broadcast on U.S. radio stations. By U.S. law, foreign governments or their representatives are not allowed to own more than 25% of a station’s U.S. parent corporation without FCC approval.In a Sept. 16 interview, Su said that he is merely a businessman and not an agent of China. “Our U.S. audience and our U.S. public has the choice,” Su said. “They can choose to listen or not listen. I think this is an American value.”Su also argued that the company is not doing anything illegal since it does not own any U.S. radio stations, but only leases air time from two radio stations.G&E Studio Inc. broadcasts over 14 different cities in the U.S., including Boston, Washington, Philadelphia and San Francisco. There are at least 33 radio stations in 14 countries in CRI’s global network.Under the Foreign Agents Registration Act, the U.S. requires anyone seeking to influence U.S. public opinion on behalf of foreign agents to register with the Justice Department. However, neither Su nor his companies are registered.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. CRI owns 60% of G&E Studio Inc.2. By law, foreign agencies are prohibited from owning more than 25% of U.S. based stations3. G&E Studio Inc. broadcast geography in the U.S.4. CRI broadcast geography in the worldVOICEOVER (in English): “Reuters reports that G&E Studio Inc., a Los Angeles-based company, is 60 percent owned by a subsidiary of China Radio International, a Chinese state-run broadcaster.”“By U.S. law, foreign governments or their representatives are not allowed to own more than 25% of a station’s U.S. parent corporation without approval.”“G&E Studio Inc. broadcasts over 14 different cities in the U.S., including Boston, Washington, Philadelphia and San Francisco.”“There are at least 33 radio stations in 14 countries in CRI’s global network.”SOURCES: http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/02/us-china-radio-fcc-idUSKCN0SR2AI20151102#ymVBFlKAM8lsT422.97http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-fcc-china-radio-20151103-story.htmlhttp://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/11/03/454333047/u-s-investigating-covert-chinese-radio-broadcast-network***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Modern cars are increasingly vulnerable to hackers
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twAs modern cars become increasingly reliant on technology it also leaves them highly susceptible to hacking. Last year, according to Cambridge News, Londoners experienced more than 6000 vehicle thefts city due to hacking. A car hack demonstration involving a Wired journalist in July showed hackers controlling a Chrysler Jeep Cherokee wirelessly from a laptop. They managed to gain remote access to the car by exploiting the vehicle celluar network and rewriting firmware on one of its chips.Hackers have also been reported to gain access to cars through Wi-Fi and bluetooth connections. Once connected, hackers may extract binary code, reverse engineer software, tamper with it and send the corrupted program back to the car. The hacker can potentially control everything from the brakes and doors, to the airbags and engine.It is estimated that by 2020, 75% of cars shipped globally will have Internet connectivity. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Car driving on highway is hacked2. Parts of car vulnerable to attack3. How hacking works4. Vulnrability of modern cars to attacksVOICEOVER (in English): “With modern cars becoming increasingly computerized, hackers are able to exploit security holes to remotely take control of vehicles.”“It is possible for a skilled hacker to get into a driver’s mobile app, a car’s entertainment center, on-board diagnostics, air bags, locks, as well critical systems like the engine and brakes.” “Hackers can use a car’s cellular, Wi-Fi or bluetooth connections to gain access. The software can then be read and altered code inserted back into the car’s computers.” “Many modern cars contain more than 100 computer processors, leaving them susceptible to hacking and privacy attacks not possible on older vehicles. Last year in London alone, software flaws helped hackers steal more than 6,000 cars.”SOURCES: Arxan, Wired, Cambridge Newshttps://www.arxan.com/under_the_hood_of_a_connected_car_hack/http://www.wired.com/2015/07/hackers-remotely-kill-jeep-highway/http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/Commuters-targeted-car-hacking-gang-crimewave/story-26915139-detail/story.html***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: British scientists create tractor beam which uses sound to move objects
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA team of British scientists has successfully created a tractor beam, that used sound to levitate objects without contact.The technology was co-developed by scientists at the Universities of Sussex and Bristol, and a company called Ultrahaptics, which made the 64 mini loudspeakers that can produce precisely timed sound waves with accuracy to the microsecond level used in the experiments, according to a press release by the University of Sussex.Scientists experimented using three acoustic fields: the first one is a tweezer-like beam that can grip, move and rotate a small object. The second one behaves like an acoustic vortex which can hold the object in space. The third field works like a cage, trapping the object. Researchers were able to move the object by simply moving the cage.The technology has been used to levitate tiny polystyrene balls that measure up to 5 mm across. However, the acoustic force could be used to levitate bigger and heavier objects by increasing the sound intensity, CBS News reported.“We can move bigger and heavier objects than we have done, but the main application is going smaller to manipulate things inside the human body,” the Guardian quoted Asier Marzo, PhD student and the lead author as saying. The team is now looking into the possibilities of adapting the technology to medical use.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Mini Loudspeakers send out sound waves 2. Depiction of a heavier object could be levitated by higher sound intensity3. Depiction of the tweezer trap4. Depiction of the vortex trap5. Depiction of the cage trapVOICEOVER (in English): “The device was made from 64 mini loudspeakers that can produce precisely timed sound waves, accurate to the microsecond level.”“By increasing the sound intensity, the acoustic force could be used to levitate bigger and heavier objects.”“Scientists experimented with three acoustic force fields: the first one is a tweezer-like beam that can grip, move and rotate an object.”“The second one behaves like a like acoustic vortex which can suspend an object in its quiet central core.”“The third acoustic field works like a cage, trapping the object inside. Scientists were able to move an object by simply moving the cage.”SOURCES: The University of Sussex, CBS News, The Guardianhttp://www.sussex.ac.uk/broadcast/read/32804http://www.cbsnews.com/news/real-life-tractor-beam-levitates-objects-using-sound-waves/http://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/oct/27/the-force-awakens-tractor-beam-becomes-a-reality***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Balloon-based capsule will take passengers into space by 2017
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twWorld View Enterprises is offering to send passengers to an altitude of 100,000 feet above the ground in a space capsule hauled up by a giant balloon for a lofty sum of $75,000, according to the enterprise’s website.Once fully inflated with helium, the balloon will expand to about the size of a football stadium. The capsule will be equipped with large windows and will be able to carry up to six passengers and two crewmen. The capsule is equipped with wifi for the journey into space. It even has a bar.The ascend into the stratosphere will take roughly 90 minutes to two hours and will cruise for another two hours before descending. The balloon will separate from the capsule at 50,000 feet above ground before the parawing glides the capsule to the landing site. The balloon will be recovered once it falls back to earth to be recycled. The total flight time will be five to six hours.On October 24, 2015, World View Enterprises launched a successful test flight with a 1,000-pound replica of the capsule. World View is now ready to begin a full-scale manned flight in mid-July of 2017 and hopes to bring the space tour to life at the end of the same year, World View chief technology officer Taber MacCallum said.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Voyager Capsule in space2. Size of the balloon3. The capsule and how many people it can carry4. Voyager Capsule ascends and cruise 5. Voyager Capsule descendsVOICEOVER (in English): “World View Enterprises is offering to send passengers to an altitude of 100,000 feet above the ground in a capsule carried up by a giant balloon.”“Once fully inflated with helium, the balloon will expand to about the size of a football stadium.”“The capsule will be equipped with large windows and will be able to carry up to six passengers and two crewmen.”“The ascent into the stratosphere will take roughly 90 minutes, and the vessel will cruise for about two hours before descending.”“The balloon will separate from the capsule at 50,000 feet above the ground, at which point the parawing will glide the capsule to the landing site.”SOURCES: http://worldviewexperience.com/http://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/world-view-enjoys-successful-test-flight/http://www.space.com/30750-world-view-space-tourism-balloon-flights.htmlhttp://www.travelwires.com/world-view-enterprises-huge-balloon-for-space-tourism-34163***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Walmart seeks permission to start drone delivery testing
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twWalmart applied to the Federal Aviation Administration on Monday for permission to test the use of drones for home deliveries and at its distribution centers and stores, reported Reuters.Walmart has been conducting indoor tests using Phantom 3 and S900 drones, both of which are manufactured by SZ DJI Technology of China, and is ready to move forward to outdoor testing, said Dan Toporek, a spokesman for Walmart.Walmart is seeking permission to use the drones to take stock of the contents inside trucks parked at its warehouses. Drones can also deliver groceries to pick-up points at store parking lots. Furthermore, Walmart wants to test whether drones can successfully make home deliveries in small residential neighborhoods after obtaining permission from the households in its flight path, according to a copy of the application reviewed by Reuters. The Federal Aviation Administration could take up to 120 days to review the application. If the FAA approves Walmart’s application, the retail giant will be joining Amazon and Google in the competition over e-commerce services.The FAA is hoping to finalize its regulations on commercial drone use in the next eight months, said FAA Deputy Administrator Michael Whitaker to Reuters.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Drones used by Walmart2. How the application process works3. Walmart wants to use the drones for inventory purposes4. Walmart wants to use the drones for grocery pick-ups5. Walmart wants to use the drones for home deliveriesVOICEOVER (in English): “Walmart is seeking permission to use Phantom 3 and S900 drones for home deliveries, distribution, and for inventory work.”“The Federal Aviation Administration could take up to 120 days to review the application.”“Walmart is hoping to use the drones to take stock of the contents inside trucks parked at its warehouses.”“Drones can also deliver groceries to pick-up points at store parking lots.”“Furthermore, Walmart wants to test whether drones can successfully make home deliveries in small residential neighborhoods.”SOURCES: Reuters, New York Timeshttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/26/us-wal-mart-stores-drones-exclusive-idUSKCN0SK2IQ20151026http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/27/business/walmart-seeks-permit-to-do-tests-with-drones.html?_r=0***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Samsung unveils wearable batteries
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA subsidiary of South Korean multinational conglomerate Samsung unveiled a new range of batteries at an exhibition in Seoul last week that are designed to be worn.The batteries are known as the Band and the Stripe, which were developed by Samsung SDI, according to Geek. They can be attached to current smart wearables.The Band is designed for smartwatches and can provide up to 50 percent more battery life. The Stripe is just 0.3 mm in depth and can be bent into different shapes, which is suitable for accessories such as necklaces and headbands, Geek reported.Both batteries are prototypes, and no official release dates have been set.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. item.title: Researchers use antibody to make leukemia cells kill each other
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twABSTRACT GOES HERE (DO NOT ADD DATELINE)A team at Scripps Research Institute has discovered a new therapy that could prove to be a safer way to battle cancer. According to the National Cancer Institute, acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is caused by an overproduction of immature white blood cells that are unable to function properly or fight infection, and interfere with normal blood cell production.Current cancer treatments stop the growth of cancer cells, but almost always damage or destroy other healthy cells, reports Medical Daily.Scientists found that applying certain antibodies to AML cells triggered them to mature into natural killer cells that support the immune system. These natural killer cells then destroy related AML cancer cells, but leave unrelated cancer cells alone, prompting researchers to call the technique fratricidin therapy, according to IFL Science.In a single day, natural killer cells in one sample destroyed 15% of their cancerous kin, suggesting that a safer, more effective form of treatment could be well on its way. The Scripps team is working to be able to test the new therapy on human patients soon.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Cancer in blood2. Current cancer treatments 3. Antibodies turn cancer cells to NK cells4. NK cells kill related cancer cells5. Sample resultsVOICEOVER (in English): “Acute Myeloid Leukemia, AML, is caused by an overproduction of immature white blood cells that are unable to function properly or fight infection, and interfere with normal blood cell production.”“Current cancer treatments stop the growth of cancer cells, but almost always damage other healthy cells. ”“Scientists found that applying certain antibodies to AML cells triggered them to mature into natural killer cells that support the immune system.”“These natural killer cells then destroy related AML cancer cells, but leave unrelated cancer cells alone, prompting researchers to call the technique fratricidin therapy.”“In a single day, natural killer cells in one sample destroyed 15% of their cancerous kin, suggesting that a safer, more effective form of treatment could be well on its way. ”SOURCES: IFL Science, San Diego Union Tribune, Scripps Research Institute, Medical Daily, National Cancer Institutehttp://www.iflscience.com/health-and-medicine/scientists-can-now-make-leukemia-cells-kill-each-otherhttp://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2015/oct/19/cancer-leukemia-nk-cells-lerner-fratricidins/http://www.scripps.edu/news/press/2015/20151019lerner.htmlhttp://www.medicaldaily.com/cancer-treatment-breakthrough-researchers-engineer-way-make-leukemia-cells-kill-each-358212http://www.cancer.gov/types/leukemia/patient/adult-aml-treatment-pdq***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Huge drugs tunnel discovered under US-Mexico border
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA massive state-of-the-art tunnel used to smuggle drugs between Mexico and the US was discovered by authorities during a raid, federal officials announced on Wednesday. The tunnel, connecting warehouses in Otay Mesa, near San Diego, and Tijuana in Mexico was discovered on Wednesday following simultaneous raids on both sides of the border.Officials said the tunnel was about 30 feet deep and around 2,400 feet long and featured lighting, (pause) a ventilation system, (pause) and rail tracks for transportation of the drugs.While pulleys were believed to be used by the smugglers for loading and unloading on the U.S. side of the tunnel, according to police. The bust came after a six-month operation by Homeland Security’s ICE division that saw undercover agents arrange to provide drivers for the smugglers.Sixteen people were arrested in Mexico and six were detained in the U.S., while a total of 12 tonnes of marijuana was recovered. Mexican police said that two of the suspects told them they were working for a drug cartel operating in the state of Jalisco a reference to the Jalisco New Generation that is linked to the cartel of Joaquin ‘El Chapo’ Guzman, who escaped from a maximum security prison in July.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Location of drug tunnel near San Diego2. Cutaway showing dimensions of the tunnel (depth 30 feet, length 2,400 feet)3. Features of the tunnel (lighting, ventilation and rails)4. Pulley system used in tunnel5. Depiction of an undercover agent striking a deal with the smugglers6. Details of bust including number of arrests (22) and amount of drugs recovered (12 tonnes)VOICEOVER (in English): "The tunnel, connecting warehouses in Otay Mesa, near San Diego, and Tijuana in Mexico was discovered on Wednesday following simultaneous raids on both sides of the border.""Officials said the tunnel was about 30 feet deep and around 2,400 feet long and featured lighting, (pause) a ventilation system, (pause) and rail tracks for transportation of the drugs.""While pulleys were believed to be used by the smugglers for loading and unloading on the US side of the tunnel, according to police.""The bust came after a six-month operation by Homeland Security’s ICE that saw undercover agents arrange to provide drivers for the smugglers.""Sixteen people were arrested in Mexico and six were detained in the US, while a total of 12 tonnes of marijuana was recovered."SOURCE: ABChttp://abcnews.go.com/US/sophisticated-super-drug-tunnel-california-mexico-discovered/story?id=34666647***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Real life ‘Death Star’ observed destroying planets in its own solar system
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA dying star is ripping apart planets in its own solar system, according to a team of astronomers who published a paper yesterday in the journal Nature.The star, called WD 1145+017, is a white dwarf in the constellation Virgo. The finding was made by Andrew Vanderburg, a graduate student at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, in March. The white dwarf was spotted by NASA’s Kepler space telescope as part of the spacecraft’s K2 mission, the Boston Globe reported.Vanderburg saw a regular dip in brightness of the white dwarf every four-and-a-half hours. This suggested an object was orbiting the white dwarf at a distance of about 840,000 kilometres, about twice the distance between Earth and the Moon. After analysing data from the ground-based telescopes, Vanderburg concluded that the signal was caused by the disintegration process of the planet by the white dwarf’s gravitational pull, ABC Australia reported.“We’ve caught a star in the act of destroying a planet in its own system,” Vanderburg told the Boston Globe. “It’s like the smoking gun.”After a regular star uses up its nuclear fuel, it expands and turns into a red giant. Red giants are hot enough to convert helium into carbon. However, when its helium fuel has been exhausted, a red giant starts to contract and become more compact, eventually turning into a white dwarf, a leftover of the star’s inner core.A white dwarf is extremely dense, and its gravitational pull is so enormous that it can tear an orbiting planet apart. Astronomers believe that when a planet orbits closer than the habitable zone, it can be disintegrated by the gravitational pull of a white dwarf.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. A regular star turns into a red giant2. A red giant turns into a white dwarf3. The strong gravitational pull of a white dwarf destroying a planet4. How a star’s mass influences its orbit5. A planet orbits closer than habitable zone and is disintegrated by a white dwarfVOICEOVER (in English): “Stars shine because they convert hydrogen into helium through a process known as nuclear fusion. After a regular star uses up its nuclear fuel, it expands and turns into a red giant.”“Red giants are hot enough to convert helium into carbon. However, when helium fuel exhausts, red giants start to contract and become more compact, eventually turning into white dwarfs, a leftover of the star’s inner core.”“A white dwarf is extremely dense. Its gravitational pull is so enormous that it can tear an orbiting planet apart.”“A star’s orbit changes when its mass changes. The change in a dying star’s orbit may ‘kick’ another planet into orbiting closer around the white dwarf.”“When the planet orbits closer than the habitable zone, it can be disintegrated by the gravitational pull of the white dwarf.”SOURCES: The Verge, ABC Australia, Boston Globe, National Geographic, Naturehttp://www.theverge.com/2015/10/21/9585994/nasa-kepler-white-dwarf-planet-discovery-virgohttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-22/zombie-star-white-dwarf-killing-planets/6873658https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2015/10/21/disintegrating-stars-can-destroy-planets-harvard-researcher-finds/ZjYCCfQBP3H8NklmyVgq7O/story.htmlhttp://science.nationalgeographic.com/science/space/universe/white-dwarfs-article/http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v526/n7574/full/nature15527.html***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: What is a Dyson sphere?
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twLast week several media outlets covered a research paper speculating, among other possibilities, what debris surrounding a distant star may be.In the paper submitted to the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, a team of scientists led by Yale postdoctoral fellow Tabetha Boyajian, researchers speculate the debris may be an asteroid belt or comets, the Atlantic reports. However, others believe the debris could be extraterrestrial megastructures.One popular idea of what the space debris might be is a Dyson Sphere an energy-absorbing megastructure that envelopes a star, reports the Independent. According to All About Space, this hypothetical megastructure functions as a power station, absorbing the star’s energy output and eventually energy from the surrounding galaxy, harnessing power from the sun in a similar fashion a solar panel. Another idea is that the structure may be a swarm of thousands of satellites tethered together, collecting energy and sending it to a central location.This is similar to the notion of space-based solar power (SBSP), where a gigantic spacecraft placed between the earth and the moon would collect energy from the sun and transmit it to earth, reports All About Space.According to the Independent, Freeman Dyson, the man who popularized the Dyson sphere concept in 1960, has sought to distance himself from the theory. However, that hasn’t stopped the concept from being widely used in science fiction, comics and television.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Shell of Dyson sphere surrounding the star2. How energy may be absorbed by the structure3. How a Dyson swarm of satellites may absorb energyVOICEOVER (in English): "One popular idea of what space debris recently discovered by NASA might be is a Dyson sphere essentially an energy-absorbing megastructure that envelopes a star.""This hypothetical planet-sized structure functions as a power station, capturing the star’s energy output …""and eventually energy from the surrounding galaxy, harnessing energy from the sun like a solar panel.""Another idea is that the structure may be a swarm of thousands of satellites tethered together, collecting energy and sending it to a central location."SOURCES: CNET, Space, All About Space, The Independent, Daily Mail, The Atlantichttp://www.cnet.com/news/the-full-story-behind-the-alien-megastructures-scientists-may-have-found-but-probably-didnt/http://www.space.com/30855-alien-life-search-kepler-megastructure.htmlhttp://www.spaceanswers.com/futuretech/what-is-a-dyson-sphere/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/giant-alien-megastructure-found-in-space-what-is-dyson-sphere-and-what-else-could-we-have-found-a6695556.htmlhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3279704/The-search-alien-MEGASTRUCTURE-begins-Radio-telescope-begins-analysing-bizarre-star-surrounded-Dyson-sphere-built-extraterrestrials.htmlhttp://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2015/10/the-most-interesting-star-in-our-galaxy/410023/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: New material from orange peel could solve mercury pollution
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA team of Australian researchers may have found a cheap, sustainable way to solve the global problem of mercury contamination. According to The Conversation, the major sources of mercury in Australian waters come from industries involved in water supply and sewage, metal manufacturing, oil and gas extraction, and mining. Mercury pollution seeps into waterways and gets turned into methylmercury by organisms in the water.The toxic substance accumulates in the tissues of seafood and fish, with those at the top of the food chain containing potentially toxic levels, thus exposing people to it mainly through ingestion. As a neurotoxin, methylmercury attacks the brain and nervous system, causing problems for the kidneys and developing fetuses.To combat this, researchers at Flinders University created a sulphur-limonene polymer using two waste products- sulfur and citrus peel to act as a mercury trap. The dark red material works by attracting mercury, which binds firmly to the polymer, turning it yellow-green in the process.With production costs relatively low, the non-toxic material may be used to coat pipes and as filters, or even in large-scale cleanup operations for heavily contaminated areas, reports Business Insider Australia. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Mercury cycle2. Fish gets caught and eaten3. Effects of mercury on the body4. Sulphur-limonene polymer5. How the polymer worksVOICEOVER (in English): “Mercury pollution seeps into waterways and gets turned into methylmercury by organisms in the water.”“The toxic substance accumulates in the tissues of seafood and fish, with those at the top of the food chain containing potentially toxic levels.” “People are exposed to it mainly through eating fish.” “As a neurotoxin, methylmercury attacks the brain and nervous system, causing problems for the kidneys and developing fetuses.”"To combat this, researchers at Flinders University created a sulphur-limonene polymer using two waste products sulfur and citrus peel to act as a mercury trap.”“The dark red material works by attracting mercury, which binds firmly to the polymer, turning it yellow-green in the process.”SOURCES: The Conversation, Business Insider, News.com.au, Environment Canadahttp://theconversation.com/we-created-a-new-material-from-orange-peel-that-can-clean-up-mercury-pollution-49355http://www.businessinsider.com.au/how-orange-peel-and-industrial-waste-could-clean-mercury-from-the-ocean-2015-10http://www.news.com.au/technology/innovation/orange-peel-and-petroleum-byproduct-may-lay-waste-to-mercury-pollution/story-fnjwubd2-1227574134229https://www.ec.gc.ca/mercure-mercury/default.asp?lang=En&n=D721AC1F-1***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: DrumPants wearable fabric sensors gives voices to the speech-impaired
item.description: EDIT NUMBER: 1833SLUG/TITLE: US-USA-TECHNOLOGY-DRUMPANTS-TAPSREUTERS HEADLINE: DrumPants wearable fabric sensors gives voices to the speech-impaired LOCATION: USARESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twDrumPants TAPS is an app aimed at giving a voice to speech-impaired individuals. The device connects to wearable fabric sensors called DrumPants. “Hitting a DrumPants trigger could now trigger a phrase on your phone,” says Tyler Freeman, creator of DrumPants and co-founder of Tappur, a San Francisco startup. TAPS stands for “trigger activated personal assistant.” Freeman collaborated with Michael Zinn, a rehabilitation support worker based in Canada, to develop the TAPS app. “People with brain injuries who had difficulty speaking, they can use this,” he says. “TAPS gives them an easy way to communicate,” The device works when the user straps the fabric sensors to their body, or use Velcro to attach them to the user’s clothes. These fabric sensors are velocity sensitive, meaning the harder they’re hit, the louder they produce sound. The system uses a “text-to-speech” engine, so it can be programmed to say what the user wants when phrases are typed into the app on a smartphone or tablet. The phrases are then assigned to each trigger. A Bluetooth enabled control unit connects the triggers to the app. This results in the app speaking for the user when the sensors are tapped. TAPS is currently beta testing. Since individuals with limited mobility still need help programming each trigger, according to Zinn, they’re developing an external keyboard for mobile devices. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. DrumPants demo by Tyler Freeman, Creator of DrumPants and Co-founder of Tappur2. DrumPants TAPS demo by Freeman3. Freeman interview4. DrumPants TAPS app5. Freeman interview6. Animation depicting DrumPants TAPS7. Next stage of DrumPants TAPSVOICEOVER (in English): [TITLE CUT - ALL CAPS, TWO DECKS, 33 CHARACTERS PER DECK]WEARABLE DEVICE AIMS TO GIVETHE SPEECH-IMPAIRED A VOICEread this VO for title cut:“DrumPants TAPS is an app that does the speaking for you”EDIT NUMBER: 1833SLUG/TITLE: US-USA-TECHNOLOGY-DRUMPANTS-TAPSREUTERS HEADLINE: DrumPants wearable fabric sensors gives voices to the speech-impaired LOCATION: USARESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twDrumPants TAPS is an app aimed at giving a voice to speech-impaired individuals. The device connects to wearable fabric sensors called DrumPants. “Hitting a DrumPants trigger could now trigger a phrase on your phone,” says Tyler Freeman, creator of DrumPants and co-founder of Tappur, a San Francisco startup. TAPS stands for “trigger activated personal assistant.” Freeman collaborated with Michael Zinn, a rehabilitation support worker based in Canada, to develop the TAPS app. “People with brain injuries who had difficulty speaking, they can use this,” he says. “TAPS gives them an easy way to communicate,” The device works when the user straps the fabric sensors to their body, or use Velcro to attach them to the user’s clothes. These fabric sensors are velocity sensitive, meaning the harder they’re hit, the louder they produce sound. The system uses a “text-to-speech” engine, so it can be programmed to say what the user wants when phrases are typed into the app on a smartphone or tablet. The phrases are then assigned to each trigger. A Bluetooth enabled control unit connects the triggers to the app. This results in the app speaking for the user when the sensors are tapped. TAPS is currently beta testing. Since individuals with limited mobility still need help programming each trigger, according to Zinn, they’re developing an external keyboard for mobile devices. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. DrumPants demo by Tyler Freeman, Creator of DrumPants and Co-founder of Tappur2. DrumPants TAPS demo by Freeman3. Freeman interview4. DrumPants TAPS app5. Freeman interview6. Animation depicting DrumPants TAPS7. Next stage of DrumPa
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,DrumPants,DrumPants 2.0,DrumPants TAPS,Tyler Freeman,Tappur,speech-impaired individuals,apps,electronic instrument,wearables,nma,next media animation,Taiwanese animators

item.title: Russia and the ESA set sites on permanent moon colony with planned landing
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twThe European Space Agency and its Russian counterpart are sending a lander to the moon’s south pole as part of their plan to settle humans permanently on Earth’s closest neighbor.In one of a number of missions led by the Russian Federal Space Agency, it and the ESA hope to land the Luna 27 probe on the moon’s South Pole Aitken Basin in 2020. The spacecraft’s mission is to assess whether or not there is enough raw material on the moon’s surface to support human life during future missions. As parts of the south pole are shielded from the heat of the sun, the region is darker and colder than other sections of the moon. The environment has allowed water to collect and freeze at the surface of the moon and scientists say that this water could be used as a potential resource for the future.The ESA already has ideas about what these future missions may be as the agency hopes to build lunar habitats in the lunar south pole as early as 2024. The agency plans to deploy inflatable domes on the moon’s surface as shelter for astronauts. 3D-printing robots will be sent to the moon and will be used to build a layer of dirt around the domes.The ESA says the lunar base they hope to build within the next decade could replace the International Space Station as the new base for astronauts to experience life in space. Scientists also hope that the moon base will help astronauts prepare for later missions to Mars. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Location of the probe landing site on the moon2. Colder temperatures in the moon’s south pole craters3. Large amounts of water-ice on the surface within the craters4. Water and other chemicals could be used to support human life on the moon5. The European Space Agency’s vision for a moon base6. Moon base will include an inflatable domeVOICEOVER (in English): “In five years, European and Russian space agencies will land the Luna 27 probe on the edge of the moon’s South Pole Aitken Basin.”“As parts of the south pole are shielded from the heat of the sun, the region is darker and colder than other areas of the moon.”“Scientists say that here, water has frozen and collected at the surface.“This water could be used as a potential resource to support future human missions at this location.”“The European Space Agency hopes to build lunar habitats on the lunar south pole as early as 2024…”“...and plans to deploy inflatable domes on the moon’s surface as shelter for astronauts. 3D-printing robots will build a layer of dirt around the domes.”SOURCES: BBC, Business Insider, Spacehttp://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-34504067http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20150712-should-we-build-a-village-on-the-moonhttp://www.businessinsider.com/european-space-agency-plans-to-build-lunarville-moon-habitat-in-2024-2015-6http://www.space.com/18175-moon-temperature.html***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Anti-drone weapon developed for civilian use in Ohio
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.tw Ohio-based Battelle Memorial Institute, a private non-profit group, has announced the development of an anti-drone weapon designed for safe civilian use. The DroneDefender is a shoulder-mounted, rechargeable rifle-like weapon that takes drones, or UAVs, offline with a blast of radio waves. The Drone Defender weighs 4.5 kilos, or 10 pounds, and can target a drone up to 400 meters, or over 1300 feet away. The rifle fires waves of electromagnetic energy tuned to common GPS and ISM frequencies, disabling the UAV by blocking it from receiving commands. Radio waves from a DroneDefender should activate the disabled drone’s safety protocol, making it hover, land or return to its point of origin. Battelle says the defender could be used to protect prisons, schools or historical sites and of course has military and law enforcement applications as well. No information on the price of the DroneDefender has yet been released, but the device is expected to go on sale in 2016.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. The DroneDefender developed by the Battelle Institute 2. Weapon shoulder-mounted 3. Device’s weight and target radius4. Radio waves hitting UAV or drone 5. The drone is incapable of receiving commands and lands 6. Applications for the DroneDefenderVOICEOVER (in English): “The Ohio-based Battelle Memorial Institute, a private nonprofit science and tech development company, has announced the creation of the DroneDefender …”“...a shoulder-mounted, rechargeable rifle-like weapon that takes UAVs offline with a blast of radio waves.” “The Drone Defender weighs just 4.5 kilos, or 10 pounds, and can target a drone up to 400 meters, or over 1300 feet away.” “The rifle fires waves of electromagnetic ene＿rgy tuned to common GPS and ISM frequencies, disabling the UAV by blocking it from receiving commands.” “The radio waves from a DroneDefender should activate the disabled drone’s safety protocol, making it hover, land or return to its point of origin.” “Battelle says the defender could be used to protect prisons, schools or historical sites and of course has military and law enforcement applications as well.” SOURCES: Engadget Digital Trends http://www.engadget.com/2015/10/14/anti-drone-rifle-shoots-down-uavs-with-radio-waves/http://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/battle-innovations-anti-drone-gun/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Wearable smart device tells you when it’s time to go to the toilet
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA Japanese company has invented a device that tells the user ahead of time when they will need to make a trip to the bathroom.The Japanese company, Triple W, named the white, rectangular device “Dfree”. It is secured to the user’s abdomen and predicts fecal excretion times by montoring internal organs through ultrasonic waves. The data is sent to an app on the user’s smartphone, which sends the user a notification telling them the the estimated time of their next bathroom visit.The device is aimed at those who suffer from fecal incontinence, the disabled, the elderly, and those who need more time to find the bathroom. It could also be useful for toddlers going through toilet training.Statistics show that by 2060, two out of every five Japanese will be aged 65 or older. Triple W believes the device will be a beneficial addition to Japan’s booming elder care industry.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Incontinent person, person in wheelchair, elderly person2. Device’s ultrasonic waves monitor internal organs 3. Device sends data to smartphones, users receive notifications4. Users are able to find bathrooms in time5. Possible use in toilet training6. Japan’s ageing population VOICEOVER (in English): “The device targets those who suffer from fecal incontinence, the disabled, the elderly, and those who simply need more time to find the bathroom.” “It is worn on your abdomen, and it monitors your bowel movements by emitting ultrasonic waves to your internal organs.” “The device then collects the data and sends it to an app on your smartphone. The app will send you notifications ...” “... telling you the estimated time of your next bathroom visit.”“The device may also prove itself useful for toilet training, although its inventors have yet to find a suitable way to attach it to a toddler.”“Japan’s aging population has led to a transformation of the elder care industry. By the year 2060, two out of every five people in Japan will be aged 65 or older.”SOURCES: Reutershttp://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/13/us-pants-toilet-idUSKCN0S71U020151013***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: New study links dietary supplements to more than 20,000 ER visits a year
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA new study by the U.S. federal government discovered that weight loss and energy boosting supplements cause more than 20,000 emergency-room visits a year, the New York Times reported. The study, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, first tracked emergency room visits at 63 hospitals in the U.S. over 10 years, then analyzed those ER visits in which a dietary supplement was implicated. It found that there were about 23,000 emergency-room visits per year linked to dietary supplements, and that more than a quarter of them occurred among people aged 20 to 34.Roughly 10 percent, or about 2,150 cases yearly, were serious enough to require hospitalization.Symptoms included, among others, severe allergic reactions, heart trouble, chest pain, nausea and vomiting, and were tied to dietary supplements including herbal pills, amino acids, and vitamins, which, according to medical experts, are often adulterated with toxic chemicals.Unlike prescription drugs, dietary supplements marketed for weight loss and energy do not have to be approved by the FDA before they are sold to consumers, and do not have to carry any safety label nor a list of side effects. Under a 1994 federal law, dietary supplements are considered safe until proved otherwise. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Emergency room visits and the ones in which dietary supplements were implicated2. Number of visits and age of people affected 3. Number of people requiring hospitalization4. Patients symptoms 5. Supplements causing the symptoms adulterated with toxic chemicalsVOICEOVER (in English): “The new study first tracked emergency room visits at 63 hospitals in the U.S. for 10 years, then analyzed those ER visits in which a dietary supplement was implicated.”“It found that there were about 23,000 emergency-room visits per year linked to dietary supplements and that more than a quarter of them occurred among people aged 20 to 34.”“Roughly 10 percent, or about 2,150 cases yearly, were serious enough to require hospitalization.”“Symptoms included, among others, severe allergic reactions, heart trouble, chest pain, nausea and vomiting...""and were tied to dietary supplements including herbal pills, amino acids and vitamins, which, according to medical experts, are often adulterated with toxic chemicals.”SOURCES: The New York Times, The New England Journal of Medicinehttp://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/10/14/dietary-supplements-lead-to-20000-e-r-visits-yearly-study-finds/?_r=0http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsa1504267***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Herbal viagra use can lead to dangerously low blood pressure
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twWhile herbal viagra claims to be purely herbal, ingredients vary per brand and are often unlisted. The FDA has warned against using these herbal supplements, as they are not subject to the same standards as prescription drugs.According to the Mayo Clinic, viagra is a prescription medication that uses Sildenafil to stimulate an erection by increasing blood flow to the penis. Herbal or natural alternatives to viagra purportedly do the same, but often have unlisted ingredients. The British National Health Service warns that some brands, such as ‘Jia Yi Jian’, include prescription-only drugs Taladafil, used for erectile dysfunction, and Sibutramine, which is used to treat obesity. This brand of herbal viagra uses double the maximum dosage of Taladafil and four times the allowed amount of Sibutramine.The danger in using herbal viagra is that unlike regular viagra, the increase in blood flow applies to other body parts as well, not just the penis. This can lead to a rapid drop in blood pressure, even restricting blood flow to vital organs, especially when taken with heart disease medication, anti-depressants, or alcohol, reports the Los Angeles Times.Compared to viagra, which sells for more than $40 for one pill, a 30-capsule bottle of herbal viagra costs much less. Herbal viagra can also be bought without a prescription, either over the counter or online.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Viagra effects2. Herbal viagra ingredients3. Herbal viagra dangerous effects4. Cost of viagra vs herbal viagra5. How easy it is to obtain herbal viagraVOICEOVER (in English): “Viagra is a prescription medication that uses Sildenafil to stimulate an erection by increasing blood flow to the penis.”“For example, in the UK, the National Health Service found that a unlicensed herbal viagra product used double the maximum dosage of Taladafil and four times the allowed dosage for Sibutramine used to treat obesity.”“The danger in using herbal viagra is that the increase in blood flow applies to other body parts as well, not just the penis.”“This can lead to a rapid drop in blood pressure, even restricting blood flow to vital organs, especially when taken with heart disease medication, anti-depressants, or alcohol.” “Compared to viagra, which sells for more than $40 for one pill, a 30-capsule bottle of herbal viagra costs much less.”“Herbal viagra can also be bought without a prescription, either over the counter or online.”SOURCES: Mirror, Los Angeles Times, Mayo Clinic, UK National Health Service, CBS, Alabama Media Group, Las Vegas Review Journalhttp://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/what-herbal-viagra-everything-you-6631166http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-lamar-odom-herbal-viagra-20151014-story.htmlhttp://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/erectile-dysfunction/expert-answers/herbal-viagra/faq-20058502http://www.nhs.uk/news/2009/04April/Pages/HerbalErectionDrugWarning.aspxhttp://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2015/10/14/what-exactly-is-herbal-viagra/http://www.al.com/news/index.ssf/2015/10/lamar_odoms_herbal_viagra_fda.htmlhttp://www.reviewjournal.com/life/health/sex-enhancement-product-ingredients-can-be-risky***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: NASA’s Kepler telescope spots possible alien megastructures surrounding huge star
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twScientists are striving to explain a recently discovered star and what its surroundings could mean for the universe.Between the Cygnus and Lyra constellations sits a peculiar star named KIC 8462852. Light patterns from this star suggest it is old. However, it is surrounded by debris like a younger star, reports Popular Mechanics.In a recent paper submitted to the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, a team of scientists, led by Tabetha Boyajian, a postdoctoral fellow at Yale University, speculate the debris may be an asteroid belt or comets, the Atlantic reports. However, in another scenario, some suggest it might be extraterrestrial megastructures. According to Popular Mechanics, extraterrestrial intelligence researchers at the University of California at Berkeley are drafting a proposal to point a large radio telescope at the star and listen for signs that may indicate technological activity. Another possibility is that the data may contain some mistakes.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Location of KIC 84628522. Light patterns and surroundings of star3. Star surrounded by asteroid belt, then comets4. Extraterrestrial megastructures5. Radio telescope listening for signs of alien technological activity VOICEOVER (in English): “Between the Cygnus and Lyra constellations sits a peculiar star named KIC 8462852.”“Light patterns from this star suggest it is old. However it is surrounded by debris like a younger star.” “What this is, is what scientists are trying to figure out.”“In a recent paper, scientists speculate the debris may be an asteroid belt or comets.”“However, in another scenario, some suggest it might be extraterrestrial megastructures.”“Extraterrestrial intelligence researchers at Berkeley are reportedly seeking to point a radio telescope at the star and listen for signs that might indicate technological activity.”SOURCES: Cornell University Library, Popular Mechanics, The Atlantichttp://arxiv.org/pdf/1509.03622v1.pdfhttp://www.popularmechanics.com/space/a17769/seti-light-blips/http://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2015/10/the-most-interesting-star-in-our-galaxy/410023/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,alien life,strange star,alien civilization,nasa aliens,nasa finds aliens,nasa kepler aliens,kepler telescope alien life,alien technology,news,politics,education,educational,news & politics

item.title: First ever ‘in womb’ stem cell trial to begin in January
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twScientists in Sweden and the UK are conducting the first clinical trial injecting stem cells into babies still in the womb to help lessen the symptoms of Brittle Bone Disease.Brittle bone disease, also known as osteogenesis imperfecta, is caused by errors in the baby’s DNA and results in poor quality or lack of collagen in the baby’s bone structure. The disease can be fatal with babies born with multiple fractures, according to the BBC.Those babies who survive will endure up to 15 bone fractures a year, brittle teeth, impaired hearing and other growth problems. The disease affects around one in every 25,000 babies, the BBC reported.The disease is incurable at the moment. Scientists from Sweden’s Karolinska Institute and UK’s Great Ormond Street Hospital will experiment with injecting stem cells from terminated pregnancies into babies with the disease in the womb and/or after they are born in an effort to see if it may lessen the symptoms of the disease, according to the BBC.“If we could reduce the fracture frequency, strengthen bone and improve growth it would have a huge impact,” the BBC quoted Dr Cecilia Gotherstrom from the Karolinska Institute as saying. “It is the first in-­man trial and, if successful, it will pave the way for other pre­natal treatments when parents have no other option.”The trial will begin in January and will be conducted across Europe. Patients are expected to participate for two years.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Depiction of brittle bone disease caused by errors in DNA2. Depiction of a baby born with fractures3. Depiction of a baby with bone fractures, brittle teeth and hearing problems4. Depiction of injecting stem cells into baby in womb5. Depiction of injecting stem cells into baby after birth6. Depiction of symptoms lessened after injection VOICEOVER (in English): “Brittle bone disease is caused by errors in the baby’s DNA and results in poor quality or a lack of collagen in its bone structure. The disease can be fatal with babies born with multiple fractures.”“Those babies who survive will endure up to 15 bone fractures a year, brittle teeth, impaired hearing and other growth problems.”“The disease affects around one in every 25,000 babies.”“Scientists are experimenting with injecting stem cells from terminated pregnancies into babies with the disease in the womb and/or after they are born, in an effort to see if it may lessen the symptoms of the disease.”SOURCES: BBChttp://www.bbc.com/news/health-34485090***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Facebook aims to give free internet access to regions in Africa by 2016
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFacebook plans to partner with Eutelsat as part of its Internet.org initiative to bring internet to billions of people around the world, starting by launching a new satellite that will provide Internet access to parts of Sub-Saharan Africa.Most of Africa is still beyond the range of traditional fixed and mobile terrestrial network connections, especially the Sub-Saharan African region.To help developing countries connect to the world of internet, Facebook and French satellite company Eutelsat will launch Spacecom’s satellite AMOS-6 and utilize it to deliver free internet access.Facebook chief executive officer, Mark Zuckerberg, said in a post online that Internet.org’s network infrastructure already includes drones and a laser communication system that are now undergoing lab tests. However, this is its first project aimed at providing Internet access from space.This project is part of Facebook’s broader Internet.org initiative that started back in 2013. The project is set to launch off in 2016.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Majority of African beyond network connections2. Facebook partner with Eutelsat to launch off AMOS-63. AMOS delivers internet access to Sub Saharan Africa4. Internet becomes accessible to the region5. Facebook’s goal to connect the worldVOICEOVER (in English): “Most of Africa is still beyond the range of traditional fixed and mobile terrestrial network connections.’’“Facebook plans to partner with French satellite company Eutelsat to launch Spacecom’s satellite AMOS-6 and utilise it to deliver internet access to Sub-Saharan Africa.’’“Facebook says this will allow users in the Sub-Saharan African region to have access to free internet.’’“The project is part of Facebook’s broader Internet.org initiative that started in 2013. Facebook is seeking to provide internet access to developing countries worldwide.’’SOURCES: Tech Crunch, Digital Trendshttp://techcrunch.com/2015/10/06/facebook-eutelsat/http://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/facebook-eutelsat-satellite-africa/https://internet.org/about***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
