item.title: New research shows elephants could help in the battle against cancer
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twIn a study published this week in the Journal of the American Medical Association, scientists reported findings of a gene in elephants that may help in the fight against cancer.Elephants, similar to humans, have lifespans of around 70 years or more, but they have 100 times more cells than humans and their cells rarely mutate into cancer. Only 4.8% of known elephant deaths are related to cancer, while for humans, cancer-related deaths are between 11% and 25%.According to the Los Angeles Times, scientists have found that African elephants have 20 copies of a gene called TP53, which creates a protein that suppresses tumors. Humans, on the other hand, inherit only one TP53: one allele from each of their parents. If one of them is defective, cancer is certain to develop sooner or later.When there is DNA damage, the gene churns out copies of its p53 protein and it either stops the cells from dividing, so the DNA can be repaired or destroy the affected cell, so it won’t pass on potentially harmful mutations.Dr Trevor Graham, a tumor biology specialist from the Barts Cancer Institute at Queen Mary University of London, told the LA Times, that reinforcing of the protection offered by TP53 in humans, would be enough to prevent human cells from becoming cancerous.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Elephants and humans lifespan and cells comparison2. Cancer rates among humans and elephants 3. Elephants gene TP53 able to suppress tumors4. Gene TP53 in humans5. Gene TP53 protein reproducing and repairing the DNA damage6. Gene TP53 protein causing damaged cells to kill themselves VOICEOVER (in English): “Elephants, similar to humans, have lifespans of around 70 years or more, but they have 100 times more cells than humans and their cells rarely mutate into cancer.”“Only 4.8% of known elephant deaths are related to cancer, while for humans, cancer-related deaths are between 11% and 25%.”“Scientists have found that African elephants have 20 copies of a gene called TP53, which creates a protein that suppresses tumors.”“Humans, on the other hand, inherit only one TP53: one allele from each of their parents. If one of them is defective, cancer is certain to develop sooner or later.”"When there is DNA damage, the gene churns out copies of its p53 protein and it either stops the cells from dividing, so the DNA can be repaired or, ""destroy the affected cell, so it won’t pass on potentially harmful mutations.”SOURCES: Los Angeles Times, The Telegraph, Nature, http://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-elephant-cancer-story-20151007-story.htmlhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/science/science-news/11917636/Why-elephants-could-hold-the-cure-for-cancer.htmlhttp://www.nature.com/news/how-elephants-avoid-cancer-1.18534***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,Cancer,cancer cure,cancer cure research,scientists,elephants,protein,gene TP53,tumors,American Medical Association,nma,next media animation,Taiwanese animators

item.title: U.S. Navy expected to sail close to islands in contested South China Sea
item.description: The United States Navy has signalled its intention to sail a surface ship close to Chinese artificial islands in the South China Sea to demonstrate Washington doesn't view the reclaimed land as sovereign territory.A U.S. official speaking to the Financial Times on the condition of anonymity said the Navy would sail a ship within the 12 nautical mile territorial zone claimed by China in the Spratly archipelago sometime within the next two weeks.The Navy Times reports that officials said the move could happen "within days," following formal approval from the Obama Administration.China claims almost the entirety of the South China Sea as its territory, a contested area extending deep into Southeast Asia. Here, China has been busy constructing artificial islands on submerged reefs and wants to enforce territorial no-go zones around this reclaimed land.Under the United Nations Law of the Sea Convention, a navy ship can may pass within 12 nautical miles of territory without conducting military operations, this is known as “innocent passage.”The U.S. Navy plans to conduct such a maneuver near the Spratly Islands to signal it doesn’t recognise China’s absolute claim on the area.China’s South China Sea claim is also contested by Brunei, Malaysia, Vietnam, the Philippines and Taiwan, countries whose 200 nautical mile exclusive economic zones overlap with China’s Claim. The U.S. says it wants to support free passage per international law.U.S. Pacific Fleet commander Admiral Scott Swift told the New York Times that Washington does not recognize any of China’s territorial claims in the area.
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,China vs US,south china sea,spratley islands,US Navy,artificial islands,Southeast Asia,nma,next media animation,Taiwanese animators

item.title: TZOA air-monitoring device can tell if your air is clean or dirty
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twTZOA, a Canada-based startup, is developing environmental-trackers for researchers and consumers to monitor air pollution. According to studies conducted by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), “indoor levels of pollutants may be two to five times ­– and occasionally more than 100 times – higher than outdoor pollutant levels.” In order to determine air quality, a small fan sucks air into the device and blows it across a laser. The laser then scatters the light from the particles onto a light detector. The system counts the number of particles by scanning the pulses of light. The intensity of the light helps determine if it’s a big particle, such as pollen, or a small particle, such as cooking pollution. Ambient conditions, such as temperature, humidity and UV are then viewed on a smartphone. TZOA also has a smaller consumer version that people can wear throughout the day. Earlier this summer, TZOA’s Indiegogo campaign raised more than $88,000, which is 152 percent of its original goal. The TZOA research costs $600 and its consumer version costs $139.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. TZOA device2. Kevin Hart, CEO of TZOA, and TZOA’s research and consumer devices3. Hart interview3. Animation depicting environmental tracking device4. Smartphone app5. Hart interview6. Comparison of TZOA devicesVOICEOVER (in English): "Kevin Hart wants you to know whether the air you’re breathing is clean or dirty. Hart is the CEO of TZOA, a Canada-based startup that’s developing environmental trackers for researchers and consumers. ""Often, outdoor air pollution can seep inside of the home. And, then you’re doing things like spreading chemicals and cooking, and you’re breathing all of this stuff in. It doesn’t have a chance to get filtered out and removed from the environment. ""A1: Air has lots of tiny particles that we can’t see with our naked eye. A2: To determine air quality, a small fan sucks air into the device and blows it across a laser.A3: The laser then scatters the light from the particles onto a light detector.A4: The system counts the number of particles by scanning the pulses of light.A5: The intensity of the light helps determine if it’s a big particle, such as pollen, or a small particle such as cooking pollution. " "Ambient conditions, such as temperature, humidity and UV are then viewed on your smartphone. ""TZOA also has a smaller consumer version that people can wear throughout the day. ""The TZOA research device is fully complete, we’re just manufacturing a production run for all of the backers and preorders that we have currently. And, the consumer device is still in production but we’ve already built the proof of concepts for it.""TZOA research is $600 and its consumer version is $139. "SOURCES: ***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Plastic eating worms might help reduce the environmental impact of garbage
item.description: Researchers led by scientists at Stanford University in U.S. and Beihang University in China have found that the mealworm can safely biodegrade various types of plastic, Stanford News reported. Americans discard about 33 million tonnes of plastic every year, less than 10 percent of which gets recycled.A solution to this problem may be the mealworm - the larvae form of the darkling beetle -which researchers in an ongoing study found can subsist on a diet of Styrofoam and other forms of polystyrene. The bacteria in the mealworm’s gut is able to biodegrade the plastic as part of its digestive process.Researchers found that 100 mealworms were able to eat between 34 and 39 milligrams of Styrofoam per day, which is about the weight of a small pill. The worms converted about half of the Styrofoam into carbon dioxide, while they excreted the bulk of the remaining plastic as biodegraded fragments.Worms on the plastic diet remained healthy, and their droppings appeared to be safe for use as soil for crops. According to a Stanford University press release, the study is important because it contradicts the belief that Styrofoam is a non-biodegradable type of plastic.“Our findings have opened a new door to solve the global plastic pollution problem,” Wei-Min Wu, a senior research engineer in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at Stanford, said in a statement.According to Christian Science Monitor, the bacteria that allows mealworms to digest Styrofoam safely was originally discovered in 2009 by a Taiwanese high-school student named Tseng I-ching. However, he was not able to find out how the process occurs. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Unrecyclable plastic garbage in the US per year 2. The worm and its plastic diet 3. The bacteria in the worm’s gut biodegrading plastic 4. A hundred mealworms eating Styrofoam 5. The worms converting the plastic into carbon dioxide and excreting biodegraded fragments 6. The worms droppings used as soil for cropsVOICEOVER (in English): “Americans discard about 33 million tonnes of plastic every year, less than 10 percent of which gets recycled.”“A solution to this problem may be the mealworm, which researchers in an ongoing study found can subsist on a diet of Styrofoam and other forms of polystyrene.” “The bacteria in the mealworm’s gut is able to biodegrade the plastic as part of its digestive process.”“Researchers found that 100 mealworms were able to eat between 34 and 39 milligrams of Styrofoam per day, which is about the weight of a small pill.”“The worms converted about half of the Styrofoam into carbon dioxide, while they excreted the bulk of the remaining plastic as biodegraded fragments.” “Worms on the plastic diet remained healthy, and their droppings appeared to be safe for use as soil for crops.”SOURCES: Stanford University, Science Alert, Environmental Science and Technology, The Christian Science Monitorhttp://news.stanford.edu/news/2015/september/worms-digest-plastics-092915.htmlhttp://www.sciencealert.com/scientists-find-worms-can-safely-eat-the-plastic-in-our-garbagehttp://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acs.est.5b02661http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/2015/0930/Could-mealworms-solve-our-plastic-problem***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: UK to build £25M Jamaican prison in prisoner transfer deal
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twUK Prime Minister David Cameron recently announced plans to sign a prisoner transfer deal that will use £25 million of British foreign aid money to build a prison in Jamaica that can fit up to 1,500 inmates.The Guardian reports that under the terms of the agreement, Jamaican prisoners in the UK with a more than four year sentence, and who still have more than 18 months left to serve by the year 2020 will be repatriated and sent to the new prison. Due to poor conditions in Jamaican prisons, inmates are unable to be deported, for fear that doing so would allow them to challenge their imprisonment under human rights law. Jamaicans make up the 3rd largest prison population of foreigners in the UK. Of the more than 600 who are currently imprisoned, roughly 69% are in for drug and violence related charges. According to the BBC, about 300 of these existing offenders are eligible to be transferred in 2020. The UK has struck similar agreements with Albania, Nigeria, Somaliland, Rwanda, and Libya. Officials have claimed the deal will save British taxpayers up to £10 million pounds in taxes per year, according to Time. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Location of new prison2. Statistics of Jamaican prisoners in the UK3. Benefits of the agreement4. Previous agreementsVOICEOVER (in English): The UK announced on Wednesday a prison transfer deal allocating 25 million pounds in foreign aid to build a prison in Jamaica big enough to fit 1,500 inmates. More than 600 Jamaican criminals make up the 3rd largest prison population of foreigners in the UK. 69% are in for drug or violence related charges. When the prison opens in 2020, those with more than 18 months left to their sentence will be sent there, reportedly saving UK taxpayers 10 million pounds a year.The UK has struck similar agreements with Albania, Nigeria, Somaliland, Rwanda, and Libya.SOURCES: BBC, The Guardian, Time, International Business Timeshttp://www.bbc.com/news/uk-34398014http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/sep/30/uk-to-repatriate-hundreds-of-jamaican-prisonershttp://time.com/4055146/uk-jamaica-prison/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/uk-build-25m-prison-jamaica-prisoner-transfer-deal-1521748***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Airbus files U.S. patent for economy class ‘sleeping boxes’
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twEuropean aircraft manufacturer Airbus has filed a patent in the United States for economy-class “sleeping boxes” for long haul international flights. According to the application filed with the United States Patent and Trademark Office, the sleeping boxes, to be made of plastic or fiber-reinforced plastic, would be stacked beside and on top of each other in the rear of the aircraft. Walls are padded for safety and boxes are positioned in such a way that passengers lie perpendicular to the direction of the flight, which is reportedly safer in the event of a crash or aircraft turbulence. Each unit would be equipped with a personal TV, reclining pillows, a reading light, and video camera, which would allow flight attendants to monitor passengers. A personal service unit consisting of an emergency oxygen mask, individual air conditioning vent, loud speaker, and lamp would also be available in each box. Passengers will still need to be strapped in, but the sleeping boxes can be occupied even during taxi, takeoff, and landing. In-flight meals will be served directly to those occupying boxes, though there is an option to buy an additional seat on top of a sleeping box. Another option is for two passengers to share a sleeping box and a seat, using them alternately. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Airbus aircraft2. Sleeping boxes3. Individual amenities4. Layout of the planeVOICEOVER (in English): Aircraft manufacturer Airbus recently filed a U.S. patent for economy class ‘sleeping boxes’ on long-haul flights.The plastic boxes, stacked beside and on top of each other, are padded for safety, with no corners or edges. Each box has a personal TV, grip rails, an emergency oxygen system, loudspeaker, aircon vent, lamp, and video camera so attendants can monitor passengers.Beds are safe to occupy during taxi, takeoff, and landing since passengers lie perpendicular to the direction of the flight. SOURCES: CNN, The Daily Mail, United States Patent and Trademark Officehttp://edition.cnn.com/2015/09/29/travel/airbus-aircraft-coach-sleeping-boxes-feat/index.htmlhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/travel/travel_news/article-3253137/Cheap-dreams-Economy-Airbus-passengers-soon-travelling-SLEEP-PODS-kitted-televisions-reclining-pillows-CCTV.htmlhttp://pdfaiw.uspto.gov/.aiw?PageNum=0&docid=20150266581&IDKey=F9C4E206F21D&HomeUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fappft.uspto.gov%2Fnetacgi%2Fnph-Parser%3FSect1%3DPTO2%2526Sect2%3DHITOFF%2526p%3D1%2526u%3D%25252Fnetahtml%25252FPTO%25252Fsearch-bool.html%2526r%3D1%2526f%3DG%2526l%3D50%2526co1%3DAND%2526d%3DPG01%2526s1%3D%252522sleeping%252Bbox%252522.TTL.%2526OS%3DTTL%2F%252522sleeping%252Bbox%252522%2526RS%3DTTL%2F%252522sleeping%252Bbox%252522***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: First 10 womb transplants in the UK approved
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twAfter a successful womb transplant operation took place in Sweden last year, 10 British women without wombs will also be given a chance to undergo the operation in a clinical trial.According to the Womb Transplant UK team website, one in 5,000 women in the UK are born without wombs or lose their wombs to cancer. Ten British women will be selected for a womb transplant clinical trial if they are under 38, are of healthy weights and have long term partners.Dr. Richard Smith, a consultant gynaecologist at the Queen Charlotte's and Chelsea Hospital, will lead the team.Before the trial starts, embryos will be created and frozen from the women’s eggs and the sperm of their partner. The women will then undergo six-hour procedures to receive wombs from donors who are declared brain dead but still have beating hearts.''Donor retrieval is a bigger operation than transplanting the uterus into the recipient,'' Dr. Smith said in a statement. ''We don't want to subject a live donor to that operation.''The women will then be placed on immunosuppressant drugs for 12 months before the embryos can be implanted to prevent the body from rejecting the donor womb. The babies will be delivered by caesarean section to avoid placing the stress and strain of labor on their new wombs.After six months, the women can choose to have another child or have the donor wombs removed. Keeping the donor wombs would require the women to stay on immunosuppressant drugs, which have side effects, including an increased risk of cancer.If the trial is successful, the first British baby from a womb transplant mother will be born in late 2017 or 2018.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Percentage of women without wombs in the UK2. Criteria of potential recipients for donor wombs3. Embryos created and frozen before the trial4. Womb transplant procedure5. Babies will be delivered by cesarean sectionVOICEOVER (in English): “One in 5,000 women in the UK are born without wombs or lose their wombs to cancer. Ten British women will be selected for a womb transplant trial if they are under 38, are of healthy weights and have long term partners.”“Before the trial starts, embryos will be created and frozen from the women’s eggs and the sperm of their partner.”“The women will then undergo six-hour procedures to receive wombs from donors who are declared brain dead but still have beating hearts.”“The women will be placed on immunosuppressant drugs for 12 months before the embryos can be implanted.”“The babies will be delivered by caesarean section to avoid placing the stress and strain of labor on their new wombs.”SOURCES: http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/sep/29/10-women-receive-go-ahead-for-first-ever-womb-transplants-in-ukhttp://www.bbc.com/news/health-34397794http://wombtransplantuk.org/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: NASA confirms evidence of liquid water on Mars
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twNASA has confirmed that there is liquid water flowing on Mars, which is a potential breakthrough in the quest to search for life beyond Earth.According to NASA scientists, liquid water runs down canyons and crater walls on Mars, leaving dark stains in the terrain. These stains, known as the recurring slope lineae or RSL occur when temperatures rise above -10 Fahrenheit. The stains disappear during the cold season.Scientists discovered perchlorate salts, which is crucial in keeping water in liquid form by lowering the freezing point of water on Mars’ surface by looking at infrared light waves reflected from the RSL. The result showed that the wavelengths are commonly associated with deliquescence, a process where salt absorbs water from the air, said Georgia Tech doctoral student Lujendra Ojha. Ojha first discovered the stains while still an undergraduate student at the University of Arizona in 2011.This is not the first time water was discovered on Mars. Earlier in 2015, NASA released evidence that showed half of the northern hemisphere of the planet was once covered in an ocean, reported the Guardian.It remains to be seen whether this discovery will prove that life exists on Mars. NASA researchers will now focus on where the water comes from, whether it be deliquescence, from melted frozen water during the summer, or caused by concentrated saline aquifers in the forms of saturated gritty rocks on the Mars’ surface.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Dark stains on Mars’ terrain2. RSL occurs when it’s hotter than -10 Fahrenheit3. Discovery of perchlorate salts4. What the salt does on Mars5. DeliquescenceVOICEOVER (in English): “According to NASA scientists, liquid water runs down canyons and crater walls on Mars, leaving dark stains in the terrain.”“These stains, known as the recurring slope lineae or RSL occur when temperatures rise above -10 Fahrenheit. The stains disappear during the cold season.”“Scientists discovered perchlorate salts on Mars’ surface by looking at infrared light waves reflected from the RSL.”“The salt is crucial in keeping water in liquid form by lowering the freezing point of water.”“One possible theory of the origin of the flow of water is deliquescence, a process where salt absorbs water from the air.”SOURCES: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/29/science/space/mars-life-liquid-water.html?_r=0http://www.theguardian.com/science/2015/sep/28/nasa-scientists-find-evidence-flowing-water-mars***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,Mars,water on mars,life on mars,liquid water on Mars,nasa,aliens,life beyond earth,nma,next media animation,Taiwanese animators

item.title: Sinkhole swallows car and caravan at Australian campground
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA large sinkhole opened up near Queensland’s Rainbow Beach, terrifying campers along Inskip Point on Saturday.Fishermen were the first to notice the shoreline quickly receding into the ocean around 10:30 pm, the Brisbane Times reports. Casey Hughes told ABC news it sounded like thunder as the sinkhole was opening.The sinkhole was 150 meters long, 50 meters wide and three meters deep. The sinkhole swallowed up one car, a caravan, a camper trailer and several tents. 140 people were evacuated from the campground, but no injuries were reported. Most of the campers were able to move their vehicles out of harm’s way before their campsites were submerged in water. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Location and overview2. Fishermen notice sinkhole developing3. Sinkhole develops4. Dimensions of sinkhole5. A car, caravan, camper trailer and tent swallowed6. 140 people were evacuated safelyVOICEOVER (in English): “A large sinkhole opened up near Queensland’s Rainbow Beach, terrifying campers along Inskip Point on Saturday.”“Fishermen were the first to notice the shoreline quickly receding into the ocean around 10:30 pm.” “Casey Hughes told ABC news it sounded like thunder as the sinkhole was opening.”“The sinkhole was 150 meters long, 50 meters wide and three meters deep.”“The sinkhole swallowed up one car, a caravan, a camper trailer and several tents.” “140 people were evacuated from the campground, but no injuries were reported.” SOURCES: ABC, Sunshine Coast Daily, Brisbane Timeshttp://mobile.abc.net.au/news/2015-09-27/major-sinkhole-swallows-vehicles-on-qld-coast/6807536http://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/news/campsite-terror-inskip-sinkhole-swallows-caravan/2787981/http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/queensland/car-no-longer-visible-in-dramatic-inskip-point-sinkhole-ranger-20150927-gjvu6b.html***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: New study finds ‘human germ cloud’ unique to each person
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA group of researchers from the University of Oregon recently published a new study in the open-access journal PeerJ, which shows that each of us emits millions of bacteria into the air that form our own personal germ cloud. While the wind may disperse particles that are shed outdoors, those that are shed indoors, especially in enclosed spaces, tend to remain The study, lead by environmental scientist Dr. James Meadows, ran two experiments and found that microbes in unoccupied and occupied spaces are distinctly different, reports Time. Several types of bacteria, like Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, and Lactobacillus, are usually found on or in humans, but the ratio differs per person.After collecting airborne and surface particles from three people who remained in a sanitized room for two to four hours, researchers further found that it was possible to distinguish each person based on the unique combination of bacteria in their microbial clouds. Differences like gender stood out as certain microbes, like lactobacillus, are more commonly found in women.Dr. Meadows’ research has several real-world applications. Understanding these findings could help shed light on how infectious diseases are transmitted, while microbial clouds, like fingerprints, may someday be useful in forensics.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Bacteria around a person2. Unoccupied vs. occupied space3. Each person’s unique germ cloud4. Different combinations of bacteriaVOICEOVER (in English): “A new study, published in the open-access journal PeerJ, has shown that the microbes we shed form our own personal germ cloud.” “Researchers found that microbes in unoccupied and occupied spaces are different, since bodies give off different particles during movement.” “After putting 3 people in a room for 4 hours, they were able to identify each person based on their unique microbial signature.” “While the types of germs emitted are more or less the same, the ratio differs per person.”“Differences like gender stand out as certain microbes, like lactobacillus, are more commonly found in women.”SOURCES: Time, Mirror, PeerJ, The Telegraph, Newsweekhttp://time.com/4044393/microbe-cloud-microbiome/http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/weird-news/germ-clouds-containing-millions-bugs-6492026https://peerj.com/articles/1258/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/health/11883473/People-emit-a-germ-cloud-of-bacteria-as-unique-as-a-fingerprint-study-finds.htmlhttp://www.newsweek.com/microbial-cloud-aka-auras-are-basically-real-375010***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,human germ cloud,germ cloud,microbial signature,human microbe cloud,microbe cloud,human bacteria cloud,bacteria cloud,university of oregon,news,politics,education,educational,news & politics

item.title: Fall officially begins with the arrival of the autumnal equinox
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twThe transition from summer to autumn is usually marked by cool breezes and leaves changing color, though officially, fall does not begin until the autumnal equinox. The Earth is split by the the equator into northern and southern hemispheres. According to National Geographic, the planet orbits the sun at an tilted angle of approximately 23.5-degrees, and it is this tilt that determines the seasons.When it’s winter in the north, that area is tilted away from the sun. When it’s summer, it’s tilted towards the sun. Because of this tilt, day and night times are not usually equal, except on the two annual equinox days, writes The Weather Network.According to the BBC, the autumnal equinox occurs every year, usually on September 22, 23, or 24. Equinox is latin for ‘equal night’, and marks the moment when the sun passes over the equator. In spring, this is known as the vernal equinox, while in fall, we know it as the autumnal equinox. On these days, daylight and nighttime are both 12 hours long. Since fall also signals harvest season, many festivals are celebrated around this time. The Chinese have the Mid-Autumn Festival, while the Jewish have Sukkot or the Feast of Tabernacles. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Earth relative to the sun2. Earth’s orbit around the sun showing change in seasons3. Exact moment of autumnal equinox4. Date and time of autumnal equinoxVOICEOVER (in English): "Earth is split into North and South by the equator. It orbits the sun at an tilted angle of approximately 23.5 degrees, and it is this tilt that determines the seasons.""When it’s winter in the north, that area is tilted away from the sun. When it’s summer, it’s tilted towards the sun. Because of this tilt, day and night times are not usually equal, except on the two annual equinox days.""Equinox is latin for ‘equal night’’, and marks the moment when the sun passes over the equator. In spring, this is known as the vernal equinox, while in fall, we know it as the autumnal equinox.""On these days, daylight and nighttime are both 12 hours long. The autumnal equinox usually occurs on September 22, 23, or 24. In 2015, it happened on September 23, at 4:21am. "SOURCES: International Business Times, The Weather Network, BBC, National Geographichttp://www.ibtimes.com/when-autumnal-equinox-2015-facts-date-quotes-traditions-start-fall-2108409http://www.theweathernetwork.com/uk/news/articles/climate-and-environment/what-is-the-september-or-autumn-equinox/57541/http://www.bbc.co.uk/weather/features/34313558http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2015/09/150922-equinox-autumn-seasons-sun-moonspace-science/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,autumnal equinox explained,fall begins,autumnal equinox,autumn equinox,fall equinox,arrival of the autumnal equinox,chaneg in seasons,science,autumnal explainer,news,politics,education,educational,news & politics

item.title: Eleven million cars affected by Volkswagen emissions test cheat
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twAutomobile manufacturer Volkswagen has admitted to cheating on emissions tests, which in turn has affected 11 million cars worldwide.Officials from the Environmental Protection Agency say Volkswagen has installed an algorithm in vehicles that switches the emissions-control on and off when one of their diesel-powered cars undergo emissions testing.Diesel engines are more durable, while diesel fuel is also cheaper and can have up to 30 percent more mileage in a gallon of fuel than petrol-powered vehicles. However, isel engines emit more nitrogen oxides into the atmosphere, which could result in smog formation, according to VOX Explained.According to VOX Explained, an independant group International Council on Clean Transportation joined forces with researchers from West Virginia University when they noticed varied emission rates during field-testing of two Volkswagen vehicles. Volkswagen admitted to tampering with the emissions test when the EPA reportedly threatened to not approve the 2016 line of diesel-powered vehicles.According to the EPA, the algorithm tracks steering wheel position, pedal movements and atmospheric pressure to determine whether the vehicle is in a lab for testing. Full emissions control will be turned on during testing and off during normal driving conditions to maximize engine performance.The cheat has resulted in vehicles emitting up to 40 times more nitrogen oxides than what is considered standard, the EPA said.Volkswagen may be fined up to US$18 billion for violating the Clean Air Act.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Volkswagen installed an algorithm2. Researchers noticed varied emission rates3. Algorithm tracks various things to determine if the car was in a lab4. Algorithm switches emissions control on during lab testing5. Algorithm switches emissions control off in regular use6. The cheat allows 40 times more nitrogen oxides emissionVOICEOVER (in English): “Officials say Volkswagen has installed an algorithm in vehicles that switches the emissions-control on and off when one of their diesel-powered cars undergo emissions testing.”“A group of researchers detected the algorithm when they noticed varied emission rates during field-testing of the vehicles.”“The algorithm tracks steering wheel position, pedal movements and atmospheric pressure to determine whether the vehicle is in a lab for testing.”“Full emissions control will be turned on during testing and off during normal driving conditions to maximize engine performance.”“The cheat has resulted in vehicles emitting up to 40 times more nitrogen oxides than what is considered standard.”SOURCES: http://www.vox.com/2015/9/21/9365667/volkswagen-clean-diesel-recall-passenger-carshttp://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-09-22/how-volkswagen-fooled-us-regulators/6793652http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2015/09/18/epa-volkswagen-used-defeat-device-to-circumvent-air-pollution-controls/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: U.S. launches massive security operations for Pope’s visit
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twAuthorities have launched one of the largest security operations in U.S. history in preparation for Pope Francis’s visit.The pope is arrives in Washington, DC on Tuesday. He will depart for New York on Thursday, and travel to Philadelphia on Saturday, where he will hold an open-air Mass, expected to be attended by more than a million people.The Secret Service is in charge of coordinating the massive security operation along with the FBI, Capitol Police, Coast Guard, Pentagon, Federal Emergency Management Agency and local police. Up to 90 staff members from 50 agencies will monitor video, radio and other communications around the clock at the Multi-Agency Communications Center, the Washington Post reported. Senior members of the Secret Service travelled to the Vatican to meet with the Pope’s security force, the Swiss Guard, ahead of the visit. The Guards also made multiple trips to Washington for security planning, KUTV reported.Vatican officials instructed Secret Service agents to not to manhandle the Pope in rope lines, a common tactic used to protect U.S. presidents. U.S. lawmakers are told to not to shake hands or touch the Pope as he walks through the House chamber, according to the Washington Post.Security measures will be extremely intense in Philadelphia, where authorities have set up three security perimeters. Along the first perimeter, incoming traffic will be blocked from the Delaware River to 38th Street and from South Street north to Girard Avenue. The second perimeter includes the Benjamin Franklin Parkway and Independence Mall areas, where no traffic, except designated vehicles, will be allowed. The third perimeter will include security checkpoints and fencing. Sections of major highways will also be closed, PennLive.com reported.Some security experts have questioned whether the level of security would bring about inconveniences that would be too extreme or even counterproductive.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Pope’s itinerary2. Security departments involved in the operations3. Secret Service agents travelling to the Vatican to meet with the Swiss Guards4. Swiss Guards travelling to Washington5. Secret Service agents not to manhold the pope in rope lines 6. Lawmakers told not to touch the pope7. Agents monitoring at a center around the clock8. Security zones in Philadelphia9. Prohibited itemsVOICEOVER (in English): “The pope arrives in Washington, DC on Tuesday. He will depart for New York on Thursday, and to Philadelphia on Saturday, where he will hold an open-air Mass, expected to be attended by more than a million people.”“The Secret Service is in charge of coordinating the massive security operation along with the FBI, Capitol Police, Coast Guard, Pentagon, Federal Emergency Management Agency and local police.”“Senior members of the Secret Service travelled to the Vatican to meet with the Pope’s security force, the Swiss Guard, ahead of the visit. The Guards also made multiple trips to Washington for security planning.”“Vatican officials instructed Secret Service agents not to manhandle the Pope in rope lines, a common tactic used to protect U.S. presidents.”“U.S. lawmakers are told not to shake hands or touch the Pope as he walks through the House chamber.”“Up to 90 staff members from 50 agencies will monitor video, radio and other communications around the clock at the Multi-Agency Communications Center.”“Security measures will be extremely intense in Philadelphia, where authorities have set up three security perimeters. Along the first perimeter, incoming traffic will be blocked from the Delaware River to 38th Street and from South Street north to Girard Avenue. The second perimeter includes the Benjamin Franklin Parkway and Independence Mall areas, where no traffic, except designated vehicles, will be allowed. The third perimeter will include security checkpoints and fencing. Sections of major highways will also be closed.”“All attendees of the Mass will need to pass a thorough s

item.title: Otter with asthma is first case diagnosed in species, needs inhaler
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twAn otter named Mishka at the Seattle Aquarium is the first ever of its species to be diagnosed with asthma and requires medication administered by inhaler every day, according to a report by Seattle’s KING 5 News. The otter pushes her nose into a nozzle on the end of an asthma inhaler, originally designed for cats, then sucks out a treat placed there by her trainer and inhales a dose of asthma medication in the process. The medicine is the same as what’s used in inhalers to treat asthma in humans.Mishka, a 1-year-old female otter who was born in the wild, had difficulty breathing during recent high levels of air pollution from forest fire smoke that blew over Seattle from eastern Washington state. It is not known whether Mishka’s asthma was originally caused by air pollution or a by lack of genetic diversity in Washington’s otter population.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Otter’s lungs show asthma symptoms2. Forest fire smoke exacerbates asthma in humans and animals 3. Asthma medicine administered to otter4. Trainer using food to train otter to take asthma medicineVOICEOVER (in English): “The Seattle Aquarium’s 1-year-old otter named Mishka suffers from asthma, an inflammation of the lung’s airways.” “Smoke from wildfires has polluted the air in Seattle, causing breathing problems for asthmatic people and possibly animals.” “Using an adapter designed for cats, Mishka’s trainer administers the same asthma medicine used by humans.” “To teach the otter to use her inhaler, Mishka’s trainer places a piece of food in the mouth piece.” SOURCES: KING 5http://www.king5.com/story/news/local/seattle/2015/09/16/sea-otter-asthma-inhaler-seattle-aquarium/32528279/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Virgin snake gives birth two years in a row in Missouri
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA captive yellow-bellied water snake at the Cape Girardeau Conservation Nature Center in Missouri has reproduced again this summer, Missouri Department of Conservation naturalist Jordi Brostoski said. The water snake, which has not been held with any other water snakes in the last eight years, also reproduced without a male counterpart in 2014.An intern of the center discovered the membranes in the snake’s cage and thought it was a joke someone played on him."I thought, ‘what joker put tomatoes in here for the snake’,” intern Kyle Morton said in a release, according to the Washington Post.The process of reproducing without a sperm donor is called parthenogenesis, where cells known as polar bodies behave like sperm and fertilize an animal’s egg. According to the conservation department, there have been no other documented cases of parthenogenesis by a yellow-bellied water snake, which usually give birth to live snakes rather than lay eggs.Scientists have contributed such phenomena to sperm that has been stored within the snake from when it was in the wild. However, stored sperm usually dies within a year, according to MDC herpetologist Jeff Briggler.Two of the offspring the snake gave birth to in 2014 survived, but none that were reproduced this year lived, Brostoski said. This type of virgin birth can be seen in some insects, fish, amphibians, birds and reptiles, including some snakes, but not mammals, according to Briggler."[The snake is] at that age where she's completely able to reproduce ... It seems like a reproductive survival technique," Brostoski said in a news release. "Without a male, she wants to go ahead and produce offspring. That's what she's driven to do."RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Water snake gives birth in 2014 and this summer2. Process of parthenogenesis3. Comparison to wild yellow-bellied watersnake4. Sperm storage inside the snakeVOICEOVER (in English): “A captive yellow-bellied water snake that has been alone for eight years has reproduced on her own again this summer after already having done so once in 2014.”“The process is called parthenogenesis, where cells known as polar bodies behave like sperm and fertilize an animal’s egg.”“Yellow-bellied water snakes usually give birth to live snakes, but this particular snake laid eggs instead.”“Scientists have contributed such phenomena to sperm stored within the snake from when it was in the wild. However, stored sperm usually dies within a year.”SOURCES: http://wishtv.com/2015/09/20/captive-snake-with-no-male-companion-gives-birth-again/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/speaking-of-science/wp/2015/09/19/lady-snake-gives-birth-after-being-alone-for-eight-years-doesnt-need-men/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,virgin snake,parthenogenesis,yellow-bellied water snake,fertilized egg without sperm,mother nature,nma,next media animation,Taiwanese animators

item.title: Study finds 96 percent of former NFL players had brain disease
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA study by the Department of Veterans Affairs and Boston University found that 87 out of 91 former NFL players tested suffered from a brain disease called chronic traumatic encephalopathy.CTE is a brain disease that researchers believe us caused by repetitive head trauma. Brain scans can detect signs of CTE, but it can only be confirmed posthumously.The disease causes a protein called tau to form around blood vessels in the frontal lobe. During stage two, sufferers may experience rage, impulsivity, or depression. Symptoms of stage three include confusion and memory loss as the tau protein spreads to other parts of the brain. Stage four is marked by dementia, as nerve cells in the brain die. During the final stages of CTE, the brain withers to roughly half the size of a normal brain.A federal judge has approved a $1 billion settlement between the NFL and thousands of ex-players. The money will go toward medical exams and concussion research among payment for damages. RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. 96 percent test positive for brain disease2. Head trauma example3. Stages 1 - 4 of CTE4. Final stages of CTE5. $1b settlement with NFLVOICEOVER (in English): “A study by the Department of Veterans Affairs and Boston University found that 87 out of 91 former NFL players tested, suffered from a brain disease called chronic traumatic encephalopathy.”“CTE is a brain disease that researchers believe to be caused by repetitive head trauma. Brain scans can detect signs of CTE, but it can only be confirmed posthumously.”“The disease causes a protein called tau to form around blood vessels in the frontal lobe. During stage two, sufferers may experience rage, impulsivity, or depression. Symptoms of stage three include confusion and memory loss as the tau protein spreads to other parts of the brain. Stage four is marked by dementia, as nerve cells in the brain die.” “During the final stages of CTE, the brain withers to roughly half the size of a normal brain.” “A federal judge has approved a $1 billion settlement between the NFL and thousands of ex-players.” SOURCES: PBS, NFLhttp://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/sports/concussion-watch/new-87-deceased-nfl-players-test-positive-for-brain-disease/http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/sports/league-of-denial/nfl-concussion-settlement-wins-final-approval-from-judge/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/09000d5d81990bdf/article/new-nfl-rules-designed-to-limit-head-injuries***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Chinese firm announces plans to build high-speed rail in the U.S.
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA unit of CRRC, China’s largest train manufacturer, has signed a deal with an American venture to build a high-speed rail between Los Angeles and Las Vegas, Reuters reported.China Railway International USA said in a joint statement with XpressWest, a private venture proposal backed by Las Vegas-based hotel and casino developer Marnell Companies, that the project had an an initial capital of $100 million. Construction could begin as early as September 2016.The 230-mile line would connect Las Vegas, Victorville, Palmdale and Los Angeles. The train would travel at speeds up to 150 miles per hour, meaning passengers could travel from Las Vegas to Los Angeles in one hour and 20 minutes, comparing to four hours by car.XpressWest had been unable to secure a federal loan or investment from within the United States for the project.China Railway International USA, is owned by a consortium made up of subsidiaries from state firms China Railway Group, CRRC Corp, China State Construction Engineering Corporation and China Railway Signal & Communication Corporation.Gary Wong, a Hong Kong-based analyst at brokerage Guotai Junan, told Reuters he estimated the project could be worth about $5 billion.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Depiction of the railway connecting Las Vegas and Los Angeles2. Depiction of the speed of the train3. Time needed to travel from Las Vegas to Los Angeles by high-speed train 4. Time needed to travel from Las Vegas to Los Angeles by car5. Depiction of XpressWest unable to get funding from within the U.S.6. Depiction of XpressWest obtaining funding from Chinese companiesVOICEOVER (in English): “The 230-mile high-speed railway would connect Las Vegas, Victorville, Palmdale and Los Angeles.”“The train would travel at speeds up to 150 miles per hour,”“meaning passengers could travel from Las Vegas to Los Angeles in 1 hour and 20 minutes, compared to four hours by car.”“XpressWest, a venture set up by Las Vegas-based hotel and casino developer Marnell Companies, was unable to secure investment for the project from within the United States. It has formed a partnership with China Railway International USA, a consortium lead by China Railway, which said the project had initial capital of $100 million.”SOURCES: Los Angeles Times, NBC News, Reuters, XpressWesthttp://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-vegas-la-chinese-high-speed-rail-20150917-story.htmlhttp://www.nbcnews.com/tech/innovation/china-help-build-las-vegas-los-angeles-high-speed-railway-n429346http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/17/china-usa-railways-idUSL4N11N1JA20150917http://www.cnbc.com/2015/09/17/chinese-firms-to-build-high-speed-rail-in-the-us.htmlhttp://www.xpresswest.com/pdf/2015-09-17-China-Railway-XpressWest-Develop-HSR.pdf***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Rare supermoon lunar eclipse to dazzle later this month
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA supermoon lunar eclipse, a phenomenon which last occurred more than three decades ago, will be visible to people in the Americas on September 27 and visible to those in Western Europe and parts of Africa early on September 28.A lunar eclipse occurs when the sun, Earth and moon align to form an exact or near-exact straight line, with the Earth in the middle. The technical term for this alignment is "syzygy", which in Greek means being paired together. While in syzygy, the Earth casts its shadow on the moon's surface.The Earth's shadow is made of an outer part called the Penumbra, a darker, central part called the Umbra, and the Antumbra, an lighter area beyond the Umbra. On September 27, the lunar eclipse will be total, meaning the moon will completely enter the Umbra for one hour and 12 minutes.The moon will not turn completely dark, however. Rather, it will turn reddish, as if hit by sunlight bent by the Earth's atmosphere, a phenomenon known as a blood moon. At the same time, another phenomenon known as a perigee supermoon will also occur.At 252,000 miles from Earth, the moon will be at its apogee, its furthest point from Earth. At its perigee, its closest point to our planet, it is about 226,000 miles away. On September 27, the moon will be at perigee and will appear to be about 14 percent larger and 30 percent brighter than an apogee full moon. This rare supermoon total lunar eclipse, which has occurred only five times since 1900, will be 100 percent visible from start to end in some parts of North America, in all of South America, in Western Europe and western Africa. The event will not be visible in East Asia.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. The moon reflecting the Sun rays 2. Sun, Earth, and moon aligned3. The Earth casting its shadow on the moon's surface4. The Earth’s three different shadow 5. The moon entering the Umbra for 1 hour and 12 minutes6. The moon turning reddish7. A perigee supermoon8. The moon elliptical orbit around the Earth9. The moon at epigee 10. The moon being at perigee 11. The moon being 14 percent bigger and 30 percent brighter 12. Supermoon total eclipse timeline13.The eclipse visibility around the worldVOICEOVER (in English): [TITLE CUT]“The moon does not produce its own light, but shines because its surface reflects the Sun's rays.”“A lunar eclipse occurs when the Sun, Earth and moon are aligned to form an exact or almost exact straight line, with the Earth in the middle.” “In this alignment, the Earth casts its shadow on the moon's surface, which temporarily does not receive any sunlight.”“The Earth's shadow is made of an outer part called the Penumbra, a darker, central part called the Umbra, and the Antumbra, a partly shaded area beyond the Umbra.”“On September 27, the lunar eclipse will be total, which means that the moon will completely enter the Umbra for 1 hour and 12 minutes.”“The moon won’t turn completely dark, however. Rather, it will turn reddish as it is hit by sunlight bent by the Earth's atmosphere, a phenomenon known as a ‘blood moon.’”“At the same time, another phenomenon known as a ‘perigee supermoon’ will also occur.”“Supermoons happen because the moon's orbit around Earth is elliptical rather than circular.” “When the moon is at its apogee, its furthest point from Earth, it’s about 252,000 miles away. “At its perigee, its closest point to our planet, the moon is about 226,000 miles away.”“On September 27, the moon will be at perigee and therefore it will appear to be about 14 percent larger and 30 brighter than an apogee full moon.”“An event like a supermoon total eclipse is quite unique. Since 1900 it has occurred only five times, in 1910, 1928, 1946, 1964 and 1982. The next one will occur in 2033.”“This rare supermoon total lunar eclipse will be 100 percent visible from start to end in some parts of North America, in all South America, in western Europe and western Africa. It will not be visib

item.title: China appears to be building third airstrip in Spratly Islands
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twChina may be building a third airstrip in the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea, according to a Washington-based think tank.Satellite images taken on September 8 show that China had reclaimed a piece of land with a retaining wall about 3,000 meters long on Mischief Reef, which is suspected to be an airstrip under construction, CNN reported. China is already building airstrips on Fiery Cross Reef and Subi Reef.“If it does turn out to be a runway, China will have three airstrips that can carry any plane the PLA [People’s Liberation Army] has to offer,” Greg Poling, the director of Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies’ Asia Maritime Transparency Initiative, told CNN.The United States says China has reclaimed some 2,000 acres, or the equivalent of around 1,500 football fields, in the Spratly Islands over the past 18 months, according to CNN.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Airstrip being built on Mischief Reef2. Chinese airstrips on Mischief, Fiery Cross and Subi reefs3. Amount of land reclaimed by China in the South China Sea over the past 18 monthsVOICEOVER (in English): “China had reclaimed a piece of land with a retaining wall about 3,000 meters long on Mischief Reef, which is suspected to be an airstrip under construction.”“If so, it would be the third Chinese airstrip under construction in the Spratly Islands. China is already building airstrips on Fiery Cross Reef and Subi Reef.”“The United States says China has reclaimed some 2,000 acres, or the equivalent of around 1,500 football fields, in the Spratly Islands over the past 18 months.”SOURCES: CNN, Asia Maritime Transparency Initiative, Reutershttp://edition.cnn.com/2015/09/15/asia/china-south-china-sea-airstrip/index.htmlhttp://amti.csis.org/mischief-reef-tracker/http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/15/us-china-southchinasea-airstrips-idUSKCN0RE28220150915***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Elon Musk suggests terraforming Mars with nuclear weapons
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twTesla CEO Elon Musk suggested Wednesday on the Late Show with Stephen Colbert that Mars could be “terraformed” through nuclear strikes to destroy its polar ice caps. Terraforming is the hypothetical process of altering a planet’s environment to make it capable of supporting terrestrial lifeforms.The average temperature on Mars is similar to that of Antarctica in winter. Destroying the poles may warm the planet, but scientists told the Los Angeles Times that this may not warm Mars enough and could also lead to unknown changes in its terrain.Another method Musk suggested would be heating the planet through greenhouse gases, but this also faces problems as Mars’ current levels of carbon dioxide are potentially suitable for plants, but poisonous to animals.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Hypothetical process of terraforming2. Nuclear bombs hitting polar ice caps on Mars3. Closeup of nuclear bombs hitting polar ice caps on Mars4. Greenhouse gas effect on MarsVOICEOVER (in English): “Terraforming is the hypothetical process of altering a planet’s environment to make it liveable.”“Tesla CEO Elon Musk recently floated the idea that Mars could be terraformed through nuclear strikes to destroy its polar ice caps.”“The average temperature on Mars is similar to Antarctica in winter. Destroying the poles may warm the planet, but scientists told the Los Angeles Times this may not warm Mars enough and could also lead to unknown changes in its terrain.”“Another slower method Musk suggested would be heating the planet through greenhouse gases, but this also faces problems, as Mars’ current levels of carbon dioxide are potentially suitable for plants, but poisonous to animals.”SOURCES: Los Angeles Times, Spacehttp://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-elon-musk-mars-20150910-htmlstory.htmlhttp://www.space.com/16907-what-is-the-temperature-of-mars.htmlhttp://www.space.com/764-mars-habitable-inject-greenhouse-gas.html***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: China plans to send the first spacecraft to land on moon’s dark side
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twChina, which landed a probe on the moon in 2013, now plans to be the first country to land a probe on the moon’s far side by 2020.The far side of the moon, most of which is never visible from Earth, has been observed by various probes, but no one has ever attempted a landing.The Chinese mission will be conducted by the Chang’e-4 spacecraft. The Chang’e-4 is able to handle a larger payload than China’s previous lunar mission, the Chang’e 3, Zou Yongliao of the Chinese Academy of Sciences' moon exploration department told China’s state-run CCTV.The Chang’e-4 will orbit the moon and look for the right spot to deploy its rover. After making a soft landing, the lunar rover will dig and collect rock samples from up to 2 meters below the surface.According to CNN, some security experts fear that China is looking to lay claim to the moon’s resources, which include water and Helium 3, a clean-burning fuel that could offer an alternative to nuclear power.The U.S. is also looking at the moon for resources, and NASA is working with private companies to find ways to mine the Earth’s satellite, CNBC News reported. Chang’e-3 landed on the moon in 2013 and released a rover called Jade Rabbit, which is still on the moon, making China the third country, after the U.S. and the former Soviet Union, to land a probe on lunar soil. Now other nations in the Asia are trying to match China’s achievements. Japan has announced it will land an unmanned rover on the moon by 2018.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. The moon’s dark side2. Electromagnetic environment of the moon’s dark side and low-frequency radio study 3. Chang'e-4 spacecraft has a larger payload than the Chang’e 34. Chang'e-4 orbiting the moon5. Chang'e-4’s probe landing and conducting geological measurements6. The moon is a source of considerable resources VOICEOVER (in English): “Called the ‘dark side,’ most of the far side of the moon is never visible from Earth because the moon’s orbital and rotational periods are nearly synchronized.”“An official at the Chinese Academy of Sciences' moon exploration department told China’s state-run CCTV that the moon’s dark side has a ‘clean electromagnetic environment, which is an ideal field for low-frequency radio study.’”“The Chinese mission will be conducted by the Chang’e-4 spacecraft, which is able to handle a larger payload than China’s previous lunar mission, the Chang’e 3.”“The Chang’e-4 will orbit the moon and look for the right spot to deploy its rover.”“After making a soft landing, the lunar rover will dig and collect rock samples from up to 2 meters below the surface.”“Some security experts fear that China is looking to lay claim to the moon’s resources, which include water and Helium 3, a clean-burning fuel that could offer an alternative to nuclear power.”SOURCES: CNN, China Times, Beijing Review, Al Jazeera, CNBC, China Dailyhttp://edition.cnn.com/2015/09/09/asia/china-moon-exploration-dark-side/http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20150910000071&cid=1104http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/09/china-spacecraft-aims-reach-dark-side-moon-150909064300824.htmlhttp://www.cnbc.com/2015/03/10/billionaire-teams-up-with-nasa-to-mine-the-moon.htmlhttp://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2015-09/09/content_21823406.htm***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Massive neolithic ritual site with 90 megaliths discovered near Stonehenge
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twIn what may prove to be the largest Neolithic site ever discovered in Britain, and possibly in Europe, archeologists have found a row of 90 megaliths near Stonehenge.The 4,500-year-old stones, which are up to 15 feet tall and five feet wide were found, thanks to the use of sophisticated ground-penetrating radar equipment, buried under a thick grassy bank. They were lying horizontally, three feet underground. It is conceivable that they originally stood vertically in the ground, like other standing stones in Britain, and that the stone line marked a ritual procession route in a gigantic ceremonial complex.Archaeologists believe the megaliths were ultimately deliberately pushed over and buried. Durrington Walls, the site where the stones were found, is 12 times the area of Stonehenge and was arranged with the same summer solstice alignment, the Telegraph reported. Another nearby wooden structure named Woodhenge was thought to represent the land of the living, while Stonehenge represented the realm of the dead.The research on this new discovery, which opens a new chapter of the Stonehenge story, will be presented at the British Science Festival in Bradford this week.Paul Garwood, an archaeologist and lead historian on the project at the University of Birmingham, was quoted by the Guardian as saying that the new discovery has changed fundamentally how researchers understand Stonehenge and the world around it.“Everything written previously about the Stonehenge landscape and the ancient monuments within it will need to be rewritten,” Garwood said.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. The stone monument made of a row of 90 megaliths2. The location of the stone monument near Stonehenge3. The stones’ height, width and material4. The stones found using ground-penetrating radar equipment5. The stones lying horizontally three feet underground 6. The stones standing vertically7. The stone line used as a ritual procession route8. The megaliths being pushed over deliberately and a bank being built on top of them9. The Durrington Walls monument going from a C-shaped structure to a roughly circular enclosure10. The Durrington Walls site diameter, the width of its ditch and the height of its bank11. Durrington Walls stone monument built on the same summer solstice alignment as Stonehenge 12. Woodhenge representing the land of the living13. Stonehenge representing the realm of the deadVOICEOVER (in English): [TITLE CUT]“The massive stone monument comprised of a row of 90 megalithic stones was found buried under a thick grassy bank beneath the prehistoric super-henge of Durrington Walls, less than two miles from Stonehenge in Wiltshire.”“The line of 4,500-year-old megaliths, which are up to 15 feet tall and 5 feet wide and are believed to be sarsen stones,was found with the use of sophisticated ground-penetrating radar equipment.”“They were lying horizontally, 3 feet underground. “It is conceivable that they originally stood vertically in the ground like other standing stones in Britain, “and that the stone line marked a ritual procession route in a gigantic ceremonial complex.”“Archaeologists believe the megaliths were eventually pushed over deliberately and a bank built on top.”“From a C-shaped monument facing the river Avon, the entire structure was later shaped into a roughly circular enclosure, now known as Durrington Walls.” “The site measures around 1,640 feet in diameter and is surrounded by a ditch up to 54 feet wide and a bank of more than 3 feet high.” “It is built on the same summer solstice alignment as Stonehenge.”“A nearby wooden structure, called Woodhenge, which archeologists are still not sure had or did not have a roof, was thought to represent the land of the living ... while Stonehenge represented the realm of the dead.”SOURCES: The Guardian, BBC, Visit Stonehenge, Sky News, The Telegraph, http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/sep/07/stone
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,monolith,obelisk,huge stone monument,superhenge,Woodhenge,neolithic ritual site,nma,next media animation,Taiwanese animators

item.title: Chinese monk ‘runs on water’ for 125 meters using plywood planks
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA Chinese Shaolin monk has managed to “run” along the surface of water for 125 meters.Shi Liliang, a monk from the Shaolin monastery in Quanzhou, Fujian province, ran along the surface of a river across 200 planks of plywood made from slices of wood veneer that had been glued together, according to Shanghaiist.The plywood planks provide enough flexibility to slightly reduce the downward pressure when being stepped on, China’s iFeng reported.Shi’s technique is to have his body tilt forward slightly and step on the planks with his toes only to reduce the amount of time needed to step on each plank, according to iFeng.Shi Liliang broke his own record of 120 meters, which was achieved in January.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. 200 pieces of plywood2. Depiction of connected plywood planks that reduce downward pressure3. Shi’s body tilts forward as he tiptoes across the plywood planks4. Shi runs along the surface of the lakeVOICEOVER (in English): “Shaolin monk Shi Liliang ran along the surface of a river across 200 planks of plywood made from slices of wood veneer that had been glued together.”“The plywood planks provide enough flexibility to slightly reduce the downward pressure when being stepped on.” “Shi’s technique is to have his body tilt forward slightly and step on the planks with his toes only to reduce the amount of time needed to step on each plank.”“Shi managed to run across the surface of the water for 125 meters.”SOURCES: Shanghaiist, iFenghttp://shanghaiist.com/2015/09/07/shaolin-monk-runs-across-water-125-meters.phphttp://fo.ifeng.com/a/20141027/40847998_0.shtml***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: Why United States border walls might fail to prevent migration
item.description: Ahead of the 2016 United States presidential election, a number of Republican hopefuls have again made US border protection a key issue and several have suggested that border walls are a key solution. The history of U.S. border protection, however, shows how unfeasible the idea of a bricks-and-mortar wall is. The construction of the so-called 2,000-mile-long “Border Wall” began in 1993 between San Diego and Tijuana. However, by 2006, only 14 miles of the fence had been completed at a cost of $39 million dollars. By 2011, 646 miles of the fence was scattered along the southwest border, with 299 miles of the existing wall made up of vehicles barriers built at an approximate cost of $1.7 million per mile and 350 miles of pedestrian fencing, built at an estimated cost of $6.5 million per mile. The project proved too expensive to finish.That same year, under the Obama administration, a virtual wall using mobile surveillance and unmanned drones covering the entire 2,000-mile border, was announced at a cost of over $7 billion. A pilot program with 53 miles of virtual surveillance was launched in Arizona. After $1 billion was spent, that project was also abandoned due to its inability to meet standards for viability and cost effectiveness.But the problem is not only financial. Physical walls have not deterred immigrants from making the trip across the border. Instead, the walls have caused a rise in migrant deaths as migrants still attempt the crossing, but in more remote and risky border areas. While doing little to prevent illegal immigration, walls create many environmental problems such as the erosion of mountains, the dumping of erosion waste into rivers and consequential flooding. A physical wall along the entire US-Mexico border is unrealistic and is not a viable solution to the United States’ immigration woes. And equally costly, virtual walls both eliminate some of the environmental issues with building a physical wall, but also invite new questions regarding the privacy rights of Americans as well as health concerns.
item.media:keywords: animation,Next Animation Studio,NAS,US security,US - Mexico border,illegal immigration,Donald Trump,immigration,US Canada border,nma,Next Media Animation,Taiwanese animators

item.title: French court recognizes woman’s allergy to Wi-Fi as disability
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twA 39-year-old woman has been granted a disability allowance by a court in Toulouse, France due to her apparent allergy to Wi-Fi.Marine Richard suffers from a condition known as electromagnetic hypersensitivity and says that exposure to mobile phones, Wi-Fi, televisions, microwaves and other gadgets causes her severe discomfort.Typical symptoms reported by those with the condition include headaches, fatigue, tingling, nausea and palpitations.Despite Richard’s claims, however, the World Health Organization has yet to find scientific studies proving the link between electromagnetic waves and the symptoms she says she’s been suffering. One highly-disputed recent study cited by Newser, however, did demonstrate such a link.Richard, a former radio producer, says she was forced to move to a remote barn without electricity in Ariège, in the French Pyrenees.Richard will now reportedly be receiving 800 euros a month in disability pay for three years following a decision handed down by a Toulouse court.In a similar case in the United States, a Massachusetts couple are asking for $250,000 in damages after their son’s school installed a wireless network, which they say caused the the 12-year-old headaches, chest pains, nosebleeds, nausea, dizziness, and rashes.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Electromagnetic waves 2. Electromagnetic hypersensitivity symptoms 3. Marine Richard living in a barn without electricity 4. Marine Richard’s disability compensationVOICEOVER (in English): [CUT 1]“Marine Richard suffers from a condition known as electromagnetic hypersensitivity and says that exposure to mobile phones, Wi-Fi, televisions, microwaves and other gadgets causes her severe discomfort.”[CUT 2]“Typical symptoms reported by those with the condition include headaches, fatigue, tingling, nausea and palpitations.”[CUT 3]“Because of these discomforts, Richard says she was forced to move to a remote barn without electricity in Ariège, in the French Pyrenees.”[CUT 4]“Richard will now reportedly be receiving 800 euros a month in disability pay for three years following a decision handed down by a Toulouse court.”SOURCES: NEWSER, THE INDEPENDENT, BBC, THE GUARDIAN, http://www.newser.com/story/212006/woman-wins-disability-payout-for-wifi-sensitivity.htmlhttp://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/woman-allergic-to-wifi-granted-disability-allowance-by-french-court-10474902.htmlhttp://www.bbc.com/news/technology-34075146http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/27/french-court-awards-woman-disability-grant-for-allergy-to-gadgets***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: How a license plate reader helped catch the Virginia TV shooter
item.description: For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twThe man believed to have shot and killed two journalists during a live broadcast in Virginia was located after a State trooper used a license plate reader to track him down.Virginia State Trooper Pamela Neff spotted Vester Lee Flanagan’s vehicle on Interstate 66 at approximately 11:20 a.m. with the aid license plate reader, Fox News reported.“As soon as it was entered, it came up with a positive hit that that vehicle just passed me less than three minutes earlier,” Fox News quoted Neff as saying. “I let my dispatch know that the vehicle has passed me and I attempted to catch up with the vehicle, which was travelling eastbound on 66.”Flanagan’s vehicle ran off the road and crashed after a car chase. He died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound later at a hospital.The Automatic License Plate Recognition system uses cameras mounted to several points on a police car. The cameras are connected to an in-car processer and to a laptop in the police car, according to IEEE Spectrum, an electrical engineering journal.The cameras automatically read licence plates numbers on passing cars. A database then queries the numbers. If the license plate is located, the system alerts the officer with an alarm and an on-screen notification, IEEE Spectrum reported.This animation depicts how Automatic License Plate Recognition system works.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. Cameras mounted to a police car2. Depiction of the cameras connected to a processor and a laptop3. An officer entering a license plate number to the system4. The cameras capturing license plates on passing cars5. The system alerts the officerVOICEOVER (in English): “The Automatic License Plate Recognition system uses infrared and visible-light cameras mounted to several points on a police car. The cameras are connected to an in-car processer and a laptop.”“Officers can enter specific license plate numbers.”“The cameras automatically read licence plates numbers on passing cars. A database then queries the numbers.”“If the license plate is located, the system alerts the officer with an alarm and an on-screen notification.”SOURCES: Fox News, IEEE Spectrum, Global Newshttp://www.foxnews.com/tech/2015/08/26/license-plate-reader-technology-picked-up-virginia-shooters-car/http://spectrum.ieee.org/cars-that-think/transportation/sensors/privacy-concerns-grow-as-us-police-departments-turn-to-license-plate-readershttp://globalnews.ca/news/2186751/how-police-used-licence-plate-reader-technology-to-locate-suspected-shooter-bryce-williams/***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377

item.title: North Dakota police allowed to use drones that fire tear gas and tasers
item.description: RESTRICTIONS: NONE For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twThanks to the work of a lobbyist who represents law enforcement and has ties with the drone industry, a bill was passed by the North Dakota state House that allows police to use armed drones, the Daily Beast reported. After obtaining a search warrant from a judge, North Dakota police can deploy drones to collect real time intelligence video for criminal evidence.These police drones, however, are now also allowed to carry “less than lethal” weapons, such as rubber bullets, pepper spray, tear gas, sound cannons and tasers.But even “less than lethal” weapons can kill. According to the Guardian, at least 39 people have been killed by police tasers in 2015.With these weapons police could potentially fire on criminal suspects from far away, much like how U.S. Air Force drone pilots bomb ISIS militants from 10,000 miles away.According to the FAA, 401 drone operations were undertaken by the Grand Forks County, North Dakota, Sheriff’s Department in the past three years. The department insists there were only 21 flights.RUNDOWN SHOWS:1. A drone recording criminal activity in a parking lot2. A drone and “less than lethal” weapons3. A drone firing pepper spray on crowds 4. Number of people killed by tasers in 20155. A police drone firing a rubber bullet and a US air force jet firing a bomb on ISIS militants 6. Number of drone missions from 2012 to September 2014 according to the FAA, and according to the Grand Forks County Sheriff’s DepartmentVOICEOVER (in English): “After obtaining a search warrant from a judge, North Dakota police can deploy drones to collect real time intelligence video for criminal evidence.” “These police drones, however, are now also allowed to carry ‘less than lethal’ weapons, like rubber bullets, pepper spray, tear gas, sound cannons, and tasers.” “But even ‘less than lethal’ weapons can kill. According to the Guardian, at least 39 people have been killed by police tasers in 2015.”“With these weapons police could potentially fire on criminal suspects from far away, much like how U.S. Air Force drone pilots bomb ISIS militants from 10,000 miles away.” “According to the FAA, 401 drone operations were undertaken by the Grand Forks County, North Dakota, Sheriff’s Department in the past three years. The department insists there were only 21 flights.”SOURCES: THE DAILY BEAST http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/08/26/first-state-legalizes-armed-drones-for-cops-thanks-to-a-lobbyist.html***For story suggestions please contact tips@nma.com.twFor technical and editorial support, please contact:Asia: +61 2 93 73 1841Europe: +44 20 7542 7599Americas and Latam: +1 800 738 8377
